sp.p: Nay, afore god, I speake simply; he may pricke his foot with a thorne, and be as much as the whole venter is worth. Besides, for a dog that neuer trauail'd before, it's a large iourney to Constantinople: I'le tell you now (and he were mine) I'ld haue some present conference with a physicion, what antidotes were good to giue him, preseruatiues against poison: for (assure you) if once your money be out, there'll be diuers attempts made against the life of the poore animal.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Thou art still dangerous.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Is signior DELIROS wife your kinswoman?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: I, sir, shee is my neece, my brothers daughter here, and my nephewes sister.

sp.speaker: SORD.
sp.p: Doe you know her, sir?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: O, God sir, Signior DELIRO, her husband, is my marchant.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I, I haue seene this gentleman there, often.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: I crie you mercy, sir: let me craue your name, pray you.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: FVNGOSO, sir.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Good signior FVNGOSO, I shall request to know you better, sir.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I am her brother, sir.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: In faire time, sir.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Come, gentlemen, I will be your conduct.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Nay, pray you, sir; we shall meet at signior DELIRO'S often.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: You shall ha' me at the Heralds office, sir, for some weeke or so, at my first comming vp. Come, CARLO.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: Methinkes, CORDATVS, he dwelt somewhat too long on this Scene; it hung i' the hand.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: I see not where he could haue insisted lesse, and t' haue made the humours perspicuous enough.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: True, as his subiect lies: but hee might haue altered the shape of his argument, and explicated 'hem better in single Scenes.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: That had beene single indeed: why? be they not the same persons in this, as they would haue beene in those? and is it not an obiect of more state, to behold the Scene full, and relieu'd with varietie of speakers to the end, then to see a vast emptie stage, and the actors come in (one by one) as if they were dropt downe with a feather, into the eye of the spectators?

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: Nay, you are better traded with these things then I, and therefore I'le subscribe to your iudgement; mary, you shall giue mee leaue to make obiections.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p:
O, what else? it's the speciall intent of the author, you should
doe so: for thereby others (that are present) may as well be satisfied, who happily would obiect the same you doe.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: So, sir: but when appeares MACILENTE againe?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Mary, hee staies but till our silence giue him leaue: here hee comes, and with him signior DELIRO, a marchant, at whose house hee is come to sojourne: Make your owne obseruation now, onely transferre your thoughts to the city, with the Scene; where, suppose they speake.

sp.l: I'Le tell you by and by, sir.
Welcome (good MACILENTE) to my house,
To sojourne euen for euer: if my best
In cares, and euery sort of good intreaty
sp.stage: Deliro cometh. His boy strewes flowres.
sp.l: May moue you stay with me.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: I thanke you, sir:
And yet the muffled fates (had it pleas'd them)
Might haue suppli'd me, from their owne full store,
Without this word (I thanke you) to a foole.
I see no reason, why that dog (call'd Chaunce)
Should fawne vpon this fellow, more then me:
I am a man, and I haue limmes, flesh, bloud,
Bones, sinewes, and a soule, as well as he:
My parts are euery way as good as his,
If I said better? why, I did not lie.
Nath'lesse, his wealth (but nodding on my wants)
Must make me bow, and crie: (I thanke you, sir.)

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: Dispatch, take heed your mistris see you not.

sp.speaker: FIDO.
sp.l: I warrant you, sir. I'le steale by her softly.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: Nay, gentle friend, be merry, raise your lookes
Out of your bosome, I protest (by heauen)
You are the man most welcome in the world.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: (I thanke you, sir,) I know my cue, I thinke.

sp.speaker: FIDO.
sp.l: Where wil you haue 'hem burne, sir?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: Here, good FIDO▪
What? shee did not see thee?

sp.speaker: FIDO.
sp.l: No, sir.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: That's well:
Strew, strew, good FIDO, the freshest flowres, so.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: What meanes this, signior DELIRO? all this censing?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: Cast in more frankincense, yet more, well said.
O, MACILENTE, I haue such a wife!
So passing faire, so passing farre vnkind,
But of such worth, and right to be vnkind,
(Since no man can be worthy of her kindnesse.)

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: What can there not?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: No, that is sure as death,
No man aliue! I doe not say, is not,
But cannot possibly be worth her kindnesse!
Nay, it is certain, let me doe her right.
How, said I? doe her right? as though I could,
As though this dull grosse tongue of mine could vtter
The rare, the true, the pure, the infinite rights,
That sit (as high as I can looke) within her!

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: This is such dotage, as was neuer heard.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: Well, this must needs be granted.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: Granted, quoth you?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: Nay, MACILENTE; doe not so discredit
The goodnesse of your iudgement to denie it,
For I doe speake the very least of her.
And I would craue, and beg no more of heauen,
For all my fortunes here, but to be able
To vtter first in fit termes, what shee is,
And then the true ioyes I conceiue in her.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: Is't possible, shee should deserue so well,
As you pretend?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: I, and shee knowes so well
Her owne deserts, that (when I striue t'enioy them)
Shee weighs the things I doe, with what shee merits:
And (seeing my worth out-weigh'd so in her graces)
Shee is so solemne, so precise, so froward,
That no obseruance I can doe to her,
Can make her kind to me: if shee find fault,
I mend that fault; and then she saies, I faulted,
That I did mend it. Now, good friend, aduise me,
How I may temper this strange splene in her.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: You are too amorous, too obsequious,
And make her too assur'd, shee may command you.
When women doubt most of their husbands loues,
They are most louing. Husbands must take heed
They giue no gluts of kindnesse to their wiues,
But vse them like their horses; whom they feed
Not with a manger— full of meat together,
But halfe a pecke at once: and keep them so
Still with an appetite to that they giue them.
He that desires to haue a louing wife,
Must bridle all the shew of that desire:
Be kind, not amorous; nor bewraying kindnesse,
As if loue wrought, but considerate duty.
" Offer no loue-rites, but let wiues still seeke them,
" For when they come vnsought, they seldome like them.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: Beleeue me, MACILENTE, this is gospell.
O, that a man were his owne man so much,
To rule himselfe thus. I will striue i'faith,
To be more strange and carelesse: yet, I hope
I haue now taken such a perfect course,
To make her kind to me, and liue contented,
That I shall find my kindnesse well return'd,
And haue no need to fight with my affections.
Shee (late) hath found much fault with euery roome
Within my house; one was too big (shee said)
Another was not furnisht to her mind,
And so through all: all which, now, I haue alter'd.
Then here, shee hath a place (on my backe-side)
Wherein shee loues to walke; and that (shee said)
Had some ill smels about it. Now, this walke
Haue I (before shee knowes it) thus perfum'd
With herbes, and flowres, and laid in diuers places,
(AS 'twere on altars, consecrate to her)
Perfumed gloues, and delicate chaines of amber,
To keepe the aire in awe of her sweet nostrils:
This haue I done, and this I thinke will please her.
Behold, shee comes.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.l: Here's a sweet stinke indeed:
What, shall I euer be thus crost, and plagu'd?
And sicke of husband? O, my head doth ake,
As it would cleaue asunder with these fauours,
All my room's alter'd, and but one poore walke
That I delighted in, and that is made
So fulsome with perfumes, that I am fear'd
(My braine doth sweat so) I haue caught the plague.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: Why (gentle wife) is now thy walke too sweet?
Thou said'st of late, it had sowre aires about it,
And found'st much fault, that I did not correct it.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.l: Why, and I did find fault, sir?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: Nay, deare wife;
I know, thou hast staid, thou hast lou'd perfumes,
No woman better.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.l: I, long since perhaps,
But now that sense is alter'd: you would haue me
(Like to a puddle, or a standing poole)
To haue no motion, nor no spirit within me.
No, I am like a pure, and sprightly riuer,
That moues for euer, and yet still the same;
Or fire, that burnes much wood, yet still one flame.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: But yesterday, I saw thee at our garden,
Smelling on roses, and on purple flowres,
And since, I hope, the humour of thy sense
Is nothing chang'd.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.l: Why, those were growing flowres,
And these, within my walke, are cut and strew'd.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: But yet they haue one sent.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.l: I! haue they so?
In your grosse iudgement. If you make no difference
Betwixt the sent of growing flowres, and cut ones,
You haue a sense to taste lamp-oile, yfaith.
And with such iudgement haue you chang'd the chambers,
Leauing no roome, that I can ioy to be in,
In all your house: and now my walke, and all,
You smoke me from, as if I were a foxe,
And long, belike, to driue me quite away.
Well, walke you there, and I'le walke where I list.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: What shall I doe? Ô, I shall neuer please her,

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: Out on thee, dotard! what starre rul'd his birth?
That brought him such a starre? blind Fortune still
Bestowes her gifts on such as cannot vse them:
How long shall I liue, ere I be so happy,
To haue a wife of this exceeding forme?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: Away, with 'hem, would I had broke a ioynt,
When I deuis'd this, that should so dislike her.
Away, beare all away.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.l: I, doe: for feare
Ought that is there should like her. O, this man,
How cunningly he can conceale himselfe!
As though he lou'd? nay, honour'd, and ador'd?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: Why, my sweet heart?

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.l: Sweetheart! Ô! better still!
And asking, why? wherefore? and looking strangely,
As if he were as white as innocence.
Alas, you'r simple, you: you cannot change,
Looke pale at pleasure, and then red with wonder:
No, no, not you! 'tis pitty o'your naturalls.
I did but cast an amorous eye, e'en now,
Vpon a paire of gloues, that somewhat lik't me,
And straight he noted it, and gaue command,
All should be ta'ne away.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: Be they nay bane then.
What, sirra, FIDO, bring in those gloues againe,
You tooke from hence.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.l: S'body, sir, but doe not,
Bring in no gloues, to spite me: if you doe—

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.l: Ay, me, most wretched; how am I misconstru'd?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: O, how shee tempts my heart-strings, with her eye,
To knit them to her beauties, or to breake?
What mou'd the heauens, that they could not make
Me such a woman? but a man, a beast,
That hath no blisse like to others. Would to heauen
(In wreake of my misfortunes) I were turn'd
To some faire water- Nymph, that (set vpon
The deepest whirle-pit of the rau'nous seas,)
My adamantine eyes might head-long hale
This iron world to me, and drowne it all.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Behold, behold, the translated gallant.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.l: O, he is welcome.

sp.p: SAue you brother, and sister, saue you, sir; I haue commendations for you out in the countrey: (I wonder they take no knowledge of my sute:) mine vncle SOCLIARDO is in towne. Sister, me thinkes, you are melancholy: why are you so sad? I thinke you tooke me for master FASTIDIVS BRISLE (sister) did you not.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Why should I take you for him?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Nay, nothing— I was lately in master FASTIDIVS his company, and, me thinkes, we are very like.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: You haue a faire sute, brother, 'giue you ioy on't.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Faith, good ynough to ride in, brother, I made it to ride in.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: O, now I see the cause of his idle demand, was his new suit.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Pray you good brother, trie, if you can change her mood.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I warrant you, let mee alone. I'le put her out of her dumps. Sister, how like you my suit?

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: O, you are a gallant in print now, brother.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Faith, how like you the fashion? it's the last edition, I assure you.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: I cannot but like it, to the desert.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Troth, sister, I was faine to borrow these spurres, I ha' left my gowne in gage for'hem, pray you lend me an angell.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Now, beshrow my heart, then.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Good truth, I'le pay you againe at my next exhibition: I had but bare ten pound of my father, and it would not reach to put me wholly into the fashion.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: I care not.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I had spurres of mine owne before, but they were not ginglers. Monsieur FASTIDIVS will be here anon, sister.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: You iest?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Neuer lend me penny more (while you line then) and that I'ld be loth to say, in truth.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: When did you see him?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Yesterday, I came acquainted with him at sir PVNTARVOLO'S: nay, sweet sister.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: I faine would know of heauen now, why yond foole
Should weare a suit of sattin? he? that rooke?
That painted jay, with such a deale of out-side?
What is his inside trow? ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.
Good heauen, giue me patience, patience, patience.
A number of these popen jayes there are,
Whom, if a man conferre, and but examine
Their inward merit, with such men as want;
Lord, lord, what things they are!

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.l: Come, when will you pay me againe, now?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.l: O god, sister!

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: Here comes another.

sp.p: SAue you, signior DELIRO: how do'st thou, sweet lady? Let mee kisse thee.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: How? a new sute? Ayme.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: And how do's master FASTIDIVS BRISKE?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Faith, liue in court, signior DELIRO; in grace, I thanke god, both of the noble masculine, and feminine. I must speake with you in priuate, by and by.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: When you please, sir.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Why looke you so pale, brother?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: S'lid, all this money is cast away, now.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: I, there's a newer edition come forth.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Tis but my hard fortune! well, I'le haue my sute chang'd, I'le goe fetch my taylor presently, but first I'le deuise a letter to my father. Ha' you any pen, and inke, sister?

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: What would you doe withall?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I would vse it. S'light, and it had come but foure daies sooner, the fashion.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: There was a countesse gaue me her hand to kisse to day, i' the presence: did me more good by that light, then— and yesternight sent her coach twise to my lodging, to intreat mee accompany her, and my sweet mistris, with some two, or three namelesse ladies more: O, I haue beene grac't by 'hem beyond all aime of affection: this 's her garter my dagger hangs in: and they doe so commend, and approue my apparell, with my iudicious wearing of it, it 's aboue wonder.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Indeed sir, 'tis a most excellent sute, and you doe weare it as extraordinary.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p:
Why, I'le tell you now (in good faith) and by this chaire, which (by the grace of god) I intend presently to sit in, I had three sutes in one
yeere, made three great ladies in loue with me: I had other three, vn-did three gentlemen in imitation: and other three, gat three other gentlemen widdowes of three thousand pound a yeere.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: O, beleeue it, sir; your good face is the witch, and your apparell the spells, that bring all the pleasures of the world into their circle.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Ah, the sweet grace of a courtier!

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Well, would my father had left mee but a good face for my portion yet; though I had shar'd the vnfortunate wit that goes with it, I had not car'd: I might haue past for somewhat i' the world then.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Why, assure you, signior, rich apparell has strange vertues: it makes him that hath it without meanes, esteemed for an excellent wit: he that enioyes it with means, puts the world in remembrance of his means: it helps the deformities of nature, and giues lustre to her beauties; makes continuall holy-day where it shines; sets the wits of ladies at worke, that otherwise would be idle: furnisheth your two-shilling ordinarie; takes possession of your stage at your new play; and enricheth your oares, as scorning to goe with your scull.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Pray you, sir, adde this; it giues respect to your fooles, makes many theeues, as many strumpets, and no fewer bankrupts.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Out, out, vnworthy to speake, where he breatheth.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: What's he, signior?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: A friend of mine, sir.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: By heauen, I wonder at you, citizens, what kinde of creatures you are!

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Why, sir?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: That you can consort your selues, with such poore seame-rent fellowes.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: He saies true.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Sir, I will assure you (how euer you esteeme of him) he's a man worthy of regard.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Why? what has he in him, of such vertue to be regarded? ha?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Mary, he is a scholler, sir.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Nothing else?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: And he is well trauail'd.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: He should get him clothes; I would cherish those good parts of trauaile in him, and preferre him to some nobleman of good place.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Sir, such a benefit should bind me to you for euer (in my friends right) and, I doubt not, but his desert shall more then answere my praise.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Why, and he had good clothes, I'ld carry him to court with me to morrow.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: He shall not want for those, sir, if gold and the whole city will furnish him.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p:
You say well, sir: faith, signior DELIRO, I am come to haue
you play the Alchymist with me, and change the species of my land, into that mettall you talke of.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: With all my heart, sir, what summe will serue you?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Faith, some three, or foure hundred.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Troth, sir, I haue promist to meet a gentleman this morning, in Paules, but vpon my returne I'le dispatch you.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: I'le accompany you thither.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: As you please, sir; but I goe not thither directly.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, I haue no other designement in hand, and therefore as good goe along.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: I were as good haue a quartane feauer follow me now, for I shall ne're bee rid of him: (being mee a cloke there, one) Still, vpon his grace at court, am I sure to bee visited; I was a beast to giue him any hope. Well, would I were in, that I am out with him, once, and— Come, signior MACILENTE, I must conferre with you, as wee goe. Nay, deare wife, I beseech thee, forsake these moods: looke not like winter thus. Here, take my keyes, open my counting houses, spread all my wealth before thee, choose any obiect that delights thee: If thou wilt eate the spirit of gold, and drinke dissolu'd pearle in wine, 'tis for thee.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: So, sir.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Nay, my sweet wife.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Good lord! how you are perfum'd! in your termes, and al! pray you leaue vs.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Come, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Adiew, sweet lady.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: I, I! Let thy words euer sound in mine eares, and thy graces disperse contentment through all my senses! O, how happy is that lady aboue other ladies, that enioyes so absolute a gentleman to her seruant! A countesse giue him her hand to kisse? ah, foolish countesse! hee's a man worthy (if a woman may speake of a mans worth) to kisse the lips of an empresse.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: What's master FASTIDIVS gone, sister?

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: I, brother (he has a face like a Cherubin!)

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Gods me, what lucke's this? I haue fetcht my taylor and all: which way went he, sister? can you tell?

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Not I, in good faith (and he has a body like an angell!)

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: How long is't since he went?

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Why, but e'en now: did you not meet him? (and a tongue able to rauish any woman i' the earth!)

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: O, for gods sake (I'le please you for your paines:) but e'en now, say you? Come, good, sir: S'lid, I had forgot it too: Sister, if any body aske for mine vncle SOGLIARDO, they shall ha' him at the Heralds office, yonder by Paules.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p:
Well, I will not altogether despaire: I haue heard of a citizens wife, has beene belou'd of a courtier; and why not I? heigh, ho: well, I
will into my priuate chamber, locke the dore to mee, and thinke ouer all his good parts, one after another.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: Well, I doubt, this last Scene will endure some grieuous torture.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: How? you feare 'twill be rackt, by some hard construction?

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: Doe not you?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: No, in good faith: vnlesse mine eyes could light mee beyond sense. I see no reason, why this should be more liable to the racke, then the rest: you'le say, perhaps, the city will not take it well, that the marchant is made here to dote so perfectly vpon his wife; and shee againe, to bee so Fastidiously affected, as shee is?

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: You haue vtter'd my thought, sir, indeed.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Why (by that proportion) the court might as wel take offence at him we call the courtier, and with much more pretext, by how much the place transcends, and goes before in dignitie and vertue: but can you imagine that any noble, or true spirit in court (whose sinowie, and altogether vn-affected graces, very worthily expresse him a courtier) will make any exception at the opening of such an emptie trunke, as this BRISKE is? or thinke his owne worth empeacht, by beholding his motley inside?

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: No sir, I doe not.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: No more, assure you, will any graue, wise citizen, or modest matron, take the obiect of this folly in DELIRO, and his wife: but rather apply it as the foile to their owne vertues. For that were to affirme, that a man, writing of NERO, should meane all Emperors: or speaking of MACHIAVEL, comprehend all States-men; or in our SORDIDO, all Farmars; and so of the rest: then which, nothing can be vtter'd more malicious, or absurd. Indeed, there are a sort of these narrow-ey'd decypherers, I confesse, that will extort strange, and abstruse meanings out of any subiect, be it neuer so conspicuous and innocently deliuer'd. But to such (where e're they sit conceal'd) let them know, the author defies them, and their writing-tables; and hopes, no sound or safe iudgement will infect it selfe with their contagious comments, who (indeed) come here only to peruert, and poison the sense of what they heare, and for nought else.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: Stay, what new Mute is this, that walkes so suspiciously?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: O, mary this is one, for whose better illustration; we must desire you to presuppose the stage, the middle isle in Paules; and that, the west end of it.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: So, sir: and what followes?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Faith, a whole volume of humour, and worthy the vnclasping.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: As how? what name doe you giue him first?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: He hath shift of names, sir: some call him APPLE IOHN, some Signior WHIFFE, mary, his maine standing name is CAVALIER SHIFT: the rest are but as cleane shirts to his natures.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: And what makes he in Paules, now?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Troth, as you see, for the aduancement of a Siquis, or two; wherein he has so varied himselfe, that if any one of 'hem take, he may hull vp and downe i' the humorous world, a little longer.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: It seemes then, he beares a very changing saile?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: O, as the wind, sir: here comes more.
THis is rare, I haue set vp my bills, without discouery.

sp.speaker: ORAN.
sp.p: What? Signior WHIFFE? what fortune has brought you into these west parts?

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Troth, signior, nothing but your rheume; I haue beene taking an ounce of tabacco hard by here, with a gentleman, and I am come to spit priuate, in Paules. Saue you sir.

sp.speaker: ORAN.
sp.p: Adieu, good signior WHIFFE.

sp.speaker: CLOVE.
sp.p: Master APPLE IOHN? you are well met: when shall we sup together; and laugh, and be fat with those good wenches? ha?

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Faith, sir, I must now leaue you, vpon a few humours, and occasions: but when you please, sir.

sp.speaker: CLOVE.
sp.p: Farewell, sweet APPLE IOHN: I wonder, there are no more store of gallants here!

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: What be these two, signior?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Mary, a couple sir, that are meere strangers to the whole scope of our play; only come to walke a turne or two, i'this Scene of Paules, by chance.

sp.speaker: ORAN.
sp.p: Same you, good master CLOVE.

sp.speaker: CLOVE.
sp.p: Sweet master ORANGE.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: How? CLOVE, and ORANGE?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: I, and they are well met, for 'tis as drie an ORANGE as euer grew: nothing, but Salutation; and, O god, sir; and, It pleases you to say so, Sir; one that can laugh at a iest for company with a most plausible, and extemporall grace; and some houre after, in priuate, aske you what it was: the other, monsieur CLOVE, is a more spic't youth: he will fit you a whole afternoone sometimes, in a booke-sellers shop, reading the Greeke, Italian, and Spanish; when he vnderstands not a word of either: if he had the tongues, to his sutes, he were an excellent linguist.

sp.speaker: CLOVE.
sp.p: Doe you heare this reported, for certainty?

sp.speaker: ORAN.
sp.p: O god, sir.
SIrrah, take my cloke: and you sir knaue, follow mee closer. If thou losest my dogge, thou shalt die a dogs death; I will hang thee.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Tut, feare him not, hee's a good leane slaue, he loues a dog well, I warrant him; I see by his lookes, I: masse hee's somwhat like him. Slud poison him, make him away with a crooked pinne, or somewhat, men; thou maist haue more security of thy life: and so sir, what? you ha' not put out your whole venter yet? ha' you?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: No, I doe want yet some fifteene, or sixteene hundred pounds: but my lady (my wife) is out of her humour; shee does not now goe.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: No? how then?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Mary, I am now enforc't to giue it out, vpon the returne of my selfe, my dogge, and my cat.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Your cat? where is shee?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: My squire has her there, in the bag: Sirrah, looke to her: How lik'st thou my change, CARLO?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, for the better, sir; your cat has nine lines, and your wife ha' but one.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Besides, shee will neuer bee sea-sicke, which will saue mee so much in conserues: when saw you signior SOGLIARDO?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I came from him but now, he is at the Heralds office yonder: he requested me to goe afore, and take vp a man or two for him in Paules, against his cognisance was ready.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: What? has he purchast armes, then?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I, and rare ones too: of as many colours, as e're you saw any fooles coat in your life. I'le goe looke among yond' bills, and I can fit him with legs to his armes—

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.stage: They goe to looke vpon the bills.
sp.p: With legs to his armes! Good: I will goe with you, sir.
COme, let's walke in Mediterraneo: I assure you, sir, I am not the least respected among ladies; but let that passe: doe you know how to goe into the presence, sir?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Why, on my feet, sir.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: No, on your head, sir: for 'tis that must beare you out, I assure you: as thus, sir. You must first haue an especial care so to weare your hat, that it oppresse not confusedly this your predominant, or fore-top; because (when you come at the presence dore) you may, with once or twice stroking vp your fore-head thus, enter, with your predominant perfect: that is, standing vp stiffe.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: As if one were frighted?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: I, sir.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Which indeed, a true feare of your mistris should doe, rather than gumme water, or whites of egges: is't not so, sir?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: An ingenious obseruation: giue mee leaue to craue your name, Sir.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: His name is, MACILENTE, sir.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Good signior MACILENTE: if this gentleman, signior DELIRO, furnish you (as he saies he will) with clothes, I will bring you, to morrow by this time, into the presence of the most diuine, and acute lady in court: you shall see sweet silent rhetorique, and dumbe eloquence speaking in her eye; but when shee speakes her selfe, such an anatomie of wit, so sinewiz'd and arteriz'd, that 'tis the goodliest modell of pleasure that euer was to behold. Oh! shee strikes the world into admiration of her; (ô, ô, ô) I cannot expresse 'hem, beleuue me.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: O, your onely admiration, is your silence, sir.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: 'Fore god, CARLO, this is good; let's reade 'hem againe. If there be any lady, or gentlewoman of good carriage, that is desirous to entertaine (to her priuate vses) a yong, straight, and vpright gentleman, of the age of fiue, or sixe and twenty at the most: who can serue in the nature of a gentleman vsher, and hath little legges of purpose, and a blacke satten fute of his owne, to goe before her in: which fute (for the more sweetning) now lies in lauander: and can hide his face with her fanne, if neede require: or sit in the cold at the staire foot for her, as well as another gentleman: Let her subscribe her name and place, and diligent respect shall be giuen. This is above measure exellent! ha?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: No, this, this! here's a fine slaue.

p.q:
IF this city, or the suburbs of the same, doe affoord any yong gentleman, of the first, second, or third head, more or lesse, whose friends are but lately deceased, and whose lands are but new come to his hands, that (to bee as exactly qualified as the best of our ordinary gallants are) is affected to entertaine the most gentlemanlike vse of tabacco: as first, to giue it the most exquisite perfume; then, to know all the delicate sweet formes for the assumption of it: as also the rare corollarie, and practice of the Cuban ebolition, EVRIPVS, and whiffe; which hee shall receiue, or take in, here at London, and euaporate at Vxbridge, or farder, if it please him. If there be any such generous spirit, that is truly enamour'd of these good faculties: May it please him, but (by a note of his hand) to specifie
the place, or ordinarie where hee vses to eate, and lie; and most sweet attendance, with tabacco, and pipes of the best sort, shall be ministred: STET QVAESO CANDIDE LECTOR.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Why this is without paralell, this!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Well, I'le marke this fellow for SOGLIARDO'S vse presently.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Or rather, SOGLIARDO, for his vse,

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Faith, either of 'hem will serue, they are both good properties: I'le designe the other a place too, that we may see him.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: No better place, then the Mitre, that we may bee spectators with you, CARLO. Soft, behold, who enters here: Signior SOGLIARDO! saue you.

sp.speaker: SOGLIARDO.
sp.p: SAue you, good sir PVNTARVOLO; your dogge's in health, sir, I see: how now, CARLO?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Wee haue ta'ne simple paines, to choose you out followers here.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Come hither, signior.

sp.speaker: CLOVE.
sp.p: Monsieur ORANGE, yond' gallants obserue vs; pr'y thee let's talke fustian a little, and gull 'hem: make 'hem beleeue we are great schollers.

sp.speaker: ORANG.
sp.p: O lord, sir.

sp.speaker: CLOVE.
sp.p: Nay, pr'y thee let's, beleeue me, you haue an excellent habit in discourse.

sp.speaker: ORANG.
sp.p: It pleases you to say so, sir.

sp.speaker: CLOVE.
sp.p: By this church, you ha' la: nay, come, begin: ARISTOTLE in his Daemonologia, approues SCALIGER for the best Nauigator in his time: and in his Hypercritiques, he reports him to be Heautontimorumenos: you vnderstand the Greeke, sir?

sp.speaker: ORANG.
sp.p: O god, sir.

sp.speaker: MACIL.
sp.p: For societies sake he does. O, here be a couple of fine tame parrats.

sp.speaker: CLOVE.
sp.p: Now, sir, whereas the Ingenuitie of the time, and the soules Synderisis are but Embrions in nature, added to the panch of Esquiline, and the Inter-vallum of the Zodiack, besides the Eclipticke line being opticke, and not mentall, but by the contemplatiue & theoricke part thereof, doth demonstrate to vs the vegetable circumference, and the ventositie of the Tropicks and whereas our intellectuall, or mincing capreall (according to the Metaphisicks) as you may reade in PLATO's Histriomastix— You conceiue me, sir?

sp.speaker: ORANG.
sp.p: O lord, sir.

sp.speaker: CLOVE.
sp.p:
Then comming to the pretty Animall, as Reason long since is fled to animalls, you know, or indeed for the more modellizing, or enamelling,
or rather diamondizing of your subiect, you shall perceiue the Hipothesis, or Galaxia, (whereof the Meteors long since had their initiall inceptions and notions) to be meerely Pithagoricall, Mathematicall, and Aristocraticall— For looke you, sir, there is euer a kinde of concinnitie and species— Let vs turne to our former discourse, for they marke vs not.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Masse, yonder 's the knight PVNTARVOLO.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: And my cousin SOGLIARDO, me thinkes.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: I, and his familiar that baunts him, the deuill with a shining face.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Let 'hem alone, obserue 'hem not.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Nay, I will haue him, I am resolute for that. By this parchment, gentlemen, I haue beene so toil'd among the Harrots yonder, you will not beleeue, they doe speake i' the strangest language, and giue a man the hardest termes for his money, that euer you knew.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: But ha' you armes? ha' your armes?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Y faith, I thanke god, I can write my selfe gentlemen now, here's my pattent, it cost me thirtie pound, by this breath.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: A very saire coat, well charg'd, and full of armorie.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Nay, it has as much varietie of colours in it, as you haue seene a cost haue, how like you the crest, sir?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: I vnderstand it not well, what is't?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Mary, sir, it is your Bore without a head Rampant.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: A Bore without a head, that's very rare!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I, and rampant too: troth, I commend the Heralds wit, hee has decyphered him well: A Swine without a head, without braine, wit, any thing indeed, ramping to gentilitie. You can blazon the rest, signior? can you not?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: O, I, I haue it in writing here of purpose, it cost me two shillings the tricking.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Let's heare, let's heare.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.stage: They salute as they meet in the vallie.
sp.p: It is the most vile, foolish, absurd, palpable, & ridiculous escutcheon, that euer this eye survis'd. Saue you, good monsieur FASTIDIVS.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Silence, good knight: on, on.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: GVRONY, of eight peeces; AZVRE and GVLES, betweene three plates; a CHEV'RON, engrailed checkey, OR, VERT, and ERMINES; on a cheefe ARGENT betweene two ANN'LETS, sables; a Bores head, PROPER.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: How's that? on a cheefe ARGENT?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.stage: Here they 〈…〉 with Puntaruolo Carlo, and Sogliardo, 〈…〉 and Orange, 〈…〉.
sp.p: On a cheefe ARGENT, a Bores head, PROPER betweene two ANN'LETS sables.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: S'lud, it's a Hogs-cheeke, and puddings in a pewter field this.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: How like you 'hem, signior?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Let the word bee, Not without mustard; your crest is very rare, sir.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: A frying pan to the crest had had no fellow.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Intreat your poore friend to walke off a little, signior, I will salute the knight.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Come, lap't vp, lap't vp.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: You are right well encountred, sir, how do's your saire dog?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: In reasonable state, sir: what citizen is that you were consorted with? a marchant of any worth?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: 'Tis signior DELIRO, sir.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Is it he? Saue you, sir.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Good sir PVNTARVOLO.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: O, what copie of foole would this place minister, to one endew'd with patience, to obserue it?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nay, looke you sir, now you are gentleman, you must carry a more exalted presence, change your mood, and habit, to a more austere forme, be exceeding proud, stand vpon your gentilitie, and scorne euery man. Speake nothing humbly, neuer discourse vnder a nobleman, though you ne're saw him butriding to the Starre-chamber, it's all one. Loue no man. Trust no man. Speake ill of no man to his face: nor well of any man behind his backe. Salute fairely on the front, and wish 'hem hang'd vpon the turne. Spread your selfe vpon his bosome publikely, whose heart you would eate in priuate. These be principles, thinke on 'hem, I'le come to you againe presently.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Sirra, keepe close; yet not so close: thy breath will thawmy ruffe.

sp.speaker: SOGI.
sp.p: O, good cousin, I am a little busie, how do's my neece? I am to walke with a knight, here.
O He is here, looke you sir, that's the gentleman.

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: What, he i'the blush-colour'd sattin?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I, he sir: though his sute blush, hee blushes not, looke you, that's the sute, sir: I would haue mine, such a sute without difference, such stuffe, such a wing, such a sleeue, such a skirt, belly, and all; therefore, pray you obserue it. Haue you a paire of tables?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Why, doe you see, sir? they say I am phantasticall: why, true, I know it, and I pursue my humour still, in contempt of this censorious age. S'light, and a man should doe nothing, but what a sort of stale iudgements about this towne will approue in him, he were a sweet asse: I'ld beg him yfaith. I ne're knew any more find fault with a fashion, then they that knew not how to put themselues in to't. For mine owne part, so I please mine owne appetite, I am carelesse what the fustie world speakes of me. Puh.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Doe you marke, how it hangs at the knee there?

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: I warrant you, sir.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: For gods sake, doe, note all: doe you see the collar, sir?

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: Feare nothing, it shall not differ in a stitch, sir.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Pray heau'n, it doe not, you'le make these linings serue? and helpe me to a chapman for the out-side, will you?

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: I'le doe my best, sir: you'le put it off presently?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I, goe with mee to my chamber, you shall haue it— but make haste of it, for the loue of a customer, for I'le fit i'my old sute, or else lie a bed, and reade the Arcadia, till you haue done.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: O, if euer you were strucke with a iest, gallants, now, now. I doe vsher the most strange peece of militarie profession, that euer was discouer'd in Insula Paulina.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Where? where?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: What is he, for a creature?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: A pimpe, a pimpe, that I haue obseru'd yonder, the rarest superficies of a humour; hee comes euery morning to emptie his hangs in Paules here: and offers vp some fiue, or sixe Hecatomb's of faces, and sighes, and away againe. Here he comes; nay, walke, walke, be not seene to note him, and we shall haue excellent sport.

sp.speaker: PVN.
sp.p: S'Lid, hee vented a sigh●'ne now, I thought he would haue blowne vp the church.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: O, you shall haue him giue a number of those false fires ere hee depart.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: See, now he is expostulating with his rapier! looke, looke.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Did you euer, in your daies, obserue better passion ouer a hilt?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Except it were in the person of a cutlers boy, or that the fellow were nothing but vapour, I should thinke it impossible.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: See, againe, he claps his sword o'the head, as who should say, well, goe to.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: O violence! I wonder the blade can containe it selfe, being so prouokt.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.l: With that, the moody squire thumpt his brest,
Andrear'd his eyen to heauen, for reuenge.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Troth, and you be good gentlemen let's make 'hem friends, and take vp the matter, betweene his rapier, and him.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nay, if you intend that, you must lay downe the matter, for this rapier (it seemes) is in the nature a hanger on, and the good gentleman would happily be rid of him.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: By my faith, and 'tis to be suspected, I'le aske him.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: O, here's rich stuffe, for lifes sake, let vs goe.
A man would wish himselfe a senselesse pillar,
Rather then view these monstrous prodigies:
Nil habet infoelix paupertas durius in se,
Quàm quòd ridiculos homines facit—

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Signior.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: At your seruice.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Will you sell your rapier?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Sbloud, he is turn'd wild vpon the question, hee lookes as hee had seene a serjeant.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Sell my rapier? now fate blesse me.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: You ask't me, if I would sell my rapier, sir?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: I did indeed.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Now, lord haue mercy vpon me.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Amen, I say still.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: S'lud sir, what should you behold in my face, sir, that should moue you (as they say, sir) to aske me, sir, if I would sell my rapier?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Nay (let me pray you, sir) bee not mou'd: I protest, I would rather haue beene silent, then any way offensiue, had I knowne your nature.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Sell my rapier? 'ods lid! Nay, sir (for mine owne part) as I am a man that has seru'd in causes, or so, so I am not apt to injure any gentleman in the degree of falling foule, but (sell my rapier?) I will tell you sir, I haue seru'd with this foolish rapier, where some of vs dare not appeare in haste, I name no man: but let that passe. (Sell my rapier?) death to my lungs. This rapier, sir, has trauail'd by my side, sir, the best part of France and the low Countrey: I haue seene Vlishing Brill, and the Haghe, with this rapier, sir, in my lord of Leysters time: and (by gods will) he that should offer to disrapier me now, I would— Looke you sir, you presume to be a gentleman of sort, and so likewise your friends here, if you haue any disposition to trauell, for the sight of seruice, or so, one, two, or all of you, I can lend you letters to diuers officers and commanders in the low Countries, that shall for my cause doe you all the good offices, that shall pertaine or belong to gentlemen of your— Please you to shew the bountie of your minde, sir, to impart some ten groates, or halfe a crowne to our vse, till our abilitie be of grow'th to returne it, and we shall thinke our selfe— Sbloud! sell my rapier?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: I pray you, what said he, signior, hee's a proper man.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Mary, he tells me, if I please to shew the bountie of my mind, to impart some ten groats to his vse, or so.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Breake his head, and giue it him.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I thought he had beene playing o' the Iewes trump, I.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p:
My rapier? no sir: my rapier is my guard, my defence, my reuenew, my honour: (if you cannot impart, be secret, I beseech you) and I will maintaine it, where there is a graine of dust, or a drop of water.
(Hard is the choise when the valiant must eat their armes, or clem:) Sell my rapier? no, my deare, I will not bee diuorc't from thee, yet, I haue euer found thee true as steele— and (you cannot impart sir?) Saue you gentlemen: (neuerthelesse if you haue a fancie to it, sir.)

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Pr'y thee away: is Signior DELIRO departed?

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Ha'you seene a pimpe out-face his owne wants better?

sp.speaker: SOG.
sp.p: I commend him, that can dissemble 'hem so well.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: True, and hauing no better a cloke for it, then he has neither.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Gods precious, what mischieuous lucke is this! adiew gentlemen.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Whither? in such haste, Monsieur FASTIDIVS?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: After my marchant, signior DELIRO, sir.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: O hinder him not, hee may hap lose his tide, a good flounder i'faith.

sp.speaker: ORAN.
sp.p: Harke you, signior WHIFFE, a word with you.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.stage: Orange and Clove call Shift aside.
sp.p: How? signior WHIFFE?

sp.speaker: ORAN.
sp.p: What was the difference betweene that gallant that's gone, and you, sir.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: No difference: he would ha'giu'n mee fiue pound for my rapier, and I refus'd it; that's all.

sp.speaker: CLOVE.
sp.p: O, was't no otherwise? wee thought you had beene vpon some termes.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: No other then you saw, sir.

sp.speaker: CLOVE.
sp.p: Adieu, good Master APPLE-IOHN.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: How? WHIFFE, and APPLE-IOHN too? Heart, what'll you say if this be the appendix, or labell to both yond' indentures?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: It may be.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Resolue vs of it, IANVS, thou that look'st euery way: or thou HERCVLES, that hast trauail'd all countries.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Nay, CARLO, spend not time in inuocations now, 'tis late.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Signior, here's a gentleman desirous of your name, sir.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Sir, my name is CAVALIER SHIFT: I am knowne sufficiently in this walke, sir.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: SHIFT? I heard your name varied e'en now, as I take it.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: True, sir, it pleases the world (as I am her excellent Tabbacconist) to giue me the stile of signior WHIFFE: as I am a poore esquire about the towne here, they call mee Master APPLE-IOHN. Varierie of good names does well, sir.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I, and good parts, to make those good names: out of which I imagine yond' bils to be yours.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Sir, if I should denie the manuscripts, I were worthie to be banisht the middle I'le, for euer.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I take your word, sir: this gentleman has subscrib'd to 'hem, and is most desirous to become your pupill. Mary you must vse expedition. Signior Insulso Sogliardo, this is the professor.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: In good time, sir, nay, good sir, house your head, doe you professe those sleights in tabacco?

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: I, doe more then professe, sir, and (if you please to bee a practitioner) I wil vndertake in one fortnight to bring you, that you shal take it plausibly in any ordinarie, theatre, or the tilt-yard, if need be, i'the most popular assembly that is.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: But you cannot bring him to the whiffe so soone?

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Yes, as soone, sir, hee shall receiue the first, second, and third whiffe, if it please him, and (vpon the receit) take his horse, drinke his three cups of Canarie, and expose one at Hounslow, a second at Stanes, and a third at Bogshot.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Baw-waw!

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: You will not serue mee, sir, will your I'le giue you more then countenance.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Pardon me, sir, I doe scorne to serue any man.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Who? he serue? Sbloud he keepes high men, and low men, he; he has a faire liuing at Fullam.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: But in the nature of a fellow, I'le bee your follower, if you please.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Sir, you shall stay, and dine with mee, and if wee can agree, weele not part in haste: I am verie bountifull to men of qualitie. Where shall we goe, signior?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Your Miter is your best house.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: I can make this dogge take as many whiffes as I list, and hee shall retaine, or efume them at my pleasure.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: By your patience, follow me, fellowes.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Sir, PVNTARVOLO!

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Pardon mee, my dogge shall not eate in his companie for a million.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nay, bee not you amaz'd, signior WHIFFE, what e're that stiffeneckt gentleman say's.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: No, for you doe not know the humour of the Dogge, as wee doe: where shall we dine, CARLO? I would faine goe to one of these ordinaries, now I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: So you may, were you neuer at any yet?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: No faith, but they say, there resorts your most choise gallants.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: True, and the fashion is, when any stranger comes in among'st 'hem, they all stand vp and stare at him, as he were some vnknowne beast, brought out of Affrick, but that'll bee help't with a good aduenturous face, you must be impudent ynough, sit downe, and vse no respect; when any thing's propounded aboue your capacitie, smile at it, make two or three faces, and 'tis excellent, they'le thinke you haue trauail'd: though you argue a whole day in silence thus, and discourse in nothing but laughter, 'twill passe. Onely (now and then) giue fire, discharge a good full oth, and offer a great wager, 'twill be admirable.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: I warrant you, I am resolute: come, good signior, there's a poore french crowne, for your ordinarie.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: It comes well, for I had not so much as the least portcullice of come before.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: I trauell with another obiection, signior, which I feare will bee enforc'd against the author, ere I can be deliuer'd of it.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: What's that, sir?

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: That the argument of his Comoedie might haue beene of some other nature, as of a duke to be in loue with a countesse, and that countesse to bee in loue with the dukes sonne, and the sonne to loue the ladies waiting maid: some such crosse wooing, with a clowne to their seruingman, better then to be thus neere, and familiarly allied to the time.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: You say well, but I would faine heare one of these autumne-judgements define once, Quid sit Comoedia? if he cannot, let him content himselfe with CICEROS definition (till hee haue strength to propose to himselfe a better) who would haue a Comoedie to be Imitatio vitae, Speculum consuetudinis, Imago veritatis; a thing throughout pleasant, and ridiculous, and accommodated to the correction of manners: if the maker haue fail'd in any particle of this, they may worthily taxe him, but if not, why— be you (that are for them) silent, as I will bee for him; and giue way to the actors.

stage.ab: with a halter about his necke.

sp.p: NAy, gods precious, if the weather and season bee so respectlesse, that beggers shall liue as well as their betters; and that my hunger, and thirst for riches, shall not make them hunger and thirst with pouertie; that my sleepes shall be brokes, and their hearts not broken; that my coffers shall bee full, and yet care; theirs emptie, and yet merry! Tis time, that a crosse should beare flesh and bloud, since flesh and bloud cannot beare this crosse.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: What, will he hang himselfe?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Faith I, it seemes his Prognostication has not kept touch with him, and that makes him despaire.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: Beshrow me, he will be out of his humour then, indeed.

sp.speaker: SOR.
sp.p:
Tut, these star-monger knaues, who would trust 'hem? one saies, darke and rainy, when 'tis as cleere as christall; another saies, tempestuous blasts, and stormes, and 'twas as calme as a milke-bowle; here bee sweet rascals for a man to credit his whole fortunes with: You skie-staring cocks-combs you, you fat braines, out vpon you; you are good for nothing
but to sweat night-caps, and make rug-gownes deare! You learned men, and haue not a legion of deuils, a vostre seruice! a vostre seruice! by heauen, I thinke I shall die a better scholler then they! but soft, how now, sirra.

sp.speaker: HINE.
sp.p: Here's a letter come from your sonne, sir.

sp.speaker: SORD.
sp.p: From my sonne, sir? what would my sonne, sir? some good newes, no doubt.

body.p: Sweet and deare father (desiring you first to send mee your blessing, which is more worth to me then gold or siluer) I desire you likewise to be aduertised, that this Shrouetide (contrary to custome) we vse alwaies to haue reuels; which is indeed dancing, and makes an excellent shew in truth; especially if wee gentlemen bee well attir'd; which our seniors note, and thinke the better of our fathers, the better we are maintain'd, and that they shall know if they come vp, and haue any thing to doe in the law: therefore, good father, these are (for your owne sake as well as mine) to re-desire you; that you let me not want, that which is fit for the setting vp of our name, in the honorable volume of gentilitie, that I may say to our calumniators, with TVLLIE, Ego sum ortus domus meae, tu occasus tuae. And thus (not doubting of your fatherly beneuolence) I humbly aske you blessing, and pray god to blesse you.

sp.p: How's this? Yours, if his owne? is he not my sonne, except he be his owne sonne? Belike this is some new kinde of subscription the gallants vse. Wel, wherefore doest thou stay, knaue? Away: goe. Here's a letter indeede! reuels? and beneuolence? is this a weather to send beneuolence? or is this a season to reuell in? Slid the deuil and all takes part to vexe me, I thinke! this letter would neuer haue come now else, now, now, when the sunne shines, and the aire thus cleere. Soule, if this hold, we shall shortly haue an excellent crop of corne spring out of the high waies: the streets, and houses of the towne will be hid with the ranknesse of the fruits, that grow therein spight of good husbandry. Goe to, I'le preuent the sight of it, come as quickly as it can, I will preuent the sight of it. I haue this remedie, heauen. Stay; I'le trie the paine thus a little, Ô, nothing, nothing. Well now, shall my sonne gaine a beneuolence by my death? or any body be the better for my gold, or so forth? No, aliue, I kept it from 'hem, and (dead) my ghost shall walke about it, and preserue it, my son and daughter shall starue ere they touch it, I haue bid it as deep as hell from the sight of heauen, and to it I goe now. Falls off.

sp.speaker: RVST. 1.
sp.p: AYe me, what pittifull sight is this! help, help, help.

sp.speaker: RVST. 2.
sp.p: How now? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: RVST. 1.
sp.p: O, here's a man has hang'd himselfe, helpe to get him againe.

sp.speaker: RVST. 2.
sp.p: Hang'd himselfe? Slid carry him afore a iustice, 'tis chance medley, o' my word.

sp.speaker: RVST. 3.
sp.p: How now, what's here to doe?

sp.speaker: RVST. 4.
sp.p: How comes this?

sp.speaker: RVST. 2.
sp.p: One has executed himselfe, contrary to order of law, and by my consent he shall answer't.

sp.speaker: RVST. 5.
sp.p: Would he were in case, to answere it.

sp.speaker: RVST. 1.
sp.p: Stand by, he recouers, giue him breath.

sp.speaker: SORD.
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: RVST. 5.
sp.p: Masse, 'twas well you went the foot-way, neighbour.

sp.speaker: RVST. 1.
sp.p: I, and I had not cut the halter.

sp.speaker: SORD.
sp.p: How! cut the halter? Aye me, I am vndone, I am vndone.

sp.speaker: RVST. 2.
sp.p: Mary, if you had not beene vndone, you had beene hang'd, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: SORD.
sp.p: You thred-bare horse-bread-eating rascals, if you would needes haue beene meddling, could you not haue vntied it, but you must out it? and in the midst too! Aye me.

sp.speaker: RVST. 1.
sp.p: Out on me, 'tis the catterpiller SORDIDO! how cursed are the poore, that the viper was blest, with this good fortune?

sp.speaker: RVST. 2.
sp.p: Nay, how accurst art thou, that art cause to the curse of the poore?

sp.speaker: RVST. 3.
sp.p: I, and to saue so wretched a caytife?

sp.speaker: RVST. 4.
sp.p: Curst be thy fingers that loos'd him.

sp.speaker: RVST. 2.
sp.p: Some desperate furie possesse thee, that thou maist hang thy selfe too.

sp.speaker: RVST. 5.
sp.p: Neuer maist thou be sau'd, that sau'd so damn'd a monster.

sp.speaker: SORDID.
sp.l: What curses breathe these men! how haue my deeds
Made my lookes differ from another mans,
That they should thus detest, and lothe my life!
Out on my wretched humour, it is that
Makes me thus monstrous in true humane eyes.
Pardon me (gentle friends) I'le make faire mends
For my foule errors past, and twenty-fold
Restore to all men, what with wrong I rob'd them:
My barnes, and garners shall stand open still
To all the poore that come, and my best graine
Be made almes-bread, to feed halfe-famisht mouthes.
Though hither to amongst you I haue liu'd,
Like an unsauourie muck-hill to my selfe,
Yet now, my gather'd heapes being spread abroad,
Shall turne to better, and more fruitfull vses.
Blesse then this man, curse him no more for sauing
My life, and soule together. O, how deeply
The bitter curses of the poore doe pierce!
I am by wonder chang'd; come in with me
And witnesse my repentance: now I proue,
" No life is blest, that is not grac't with loue.

sp.speaker: RVST. 2.
sp.p: O miracle! see when a man ha's grace!

sp.speaker: RVST. 3.
sp.p: Had't not beene pitty, so good a man should haue beene cast away?

sp.speaker: RVST. 2.
sp.p: Well, I'le get our clarke put his conuersion in the Acts, and Monuments.

sp.speaker: RVST. 4.
sp.p: Doe, for I warrant him hee's a Martyr.

sp.speaker: RVST.
sp.p: O god, how he wept, if you mark't it! did you see how the teares trill'd?

sp.speaker: RVST. 5.
sp.p: Yes, beleeue me, like master vicars bowles vpon the greene, for all the world.

sp.speaker: 3. or 4.
sp.p: O neighbour, god's blessing o' your heart, neighbour, 'twas a good gratefull deed.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: How now, MITIS? what's that you consider so seriously?

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: Troth, that which doth essentially please me, the warping condition of this greene, and soggy multitude: but in good saith, signior, your author hath largely out-stript my expectation in this Scene, I will liberally confesse it. For, when I saw SORDIDO so desperately intended, I thought I had had a hand of him, then.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: What? you suppos'd he should haue hung himselfe, indeed?

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: I did, and had fram'd my obiection to it ready, which may yet be very fitly vrg'd, and with some necessity: for though his purpos'd violence lost th' effect, and extended not to death, yet the intent and horror of the obiect, was more then the nature of a Comoedie will in any sort admit.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: I? what thinke you of PLAVTVS, in his Comoedie, called Cistellaria, there? where he brings in ALCESIMARCHVS with a drawne sword ready to kill himselfe, and as hee is e'ne fixing his brest vpon it, to bee restrain'd from his resolu'd outrage, by SILENIVM, and the bawd: is not his authoritie of power to giue our Scene approbation?

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: Sir, I haue this only euasion left me, to say, I thinke it bee so indeed, your memorie is happier then mine: but I wonder, what engine hee will vse to bring the rest out of their humours!

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p:
That will appeare anon, neuer preoccupie your imagination
withall. Let your mind keepe companie with the Scene still, which now remoues it selfe from the countrey, to the court. Here comes MACILENTE, and signior BRISKE, freshly suted, lose not your selfe, for now the Epitasis, or busie part of our subiect, is in act.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: WEll, now, signior MACILENTE, you are not onely welcome to the court but also to my mistris withdrawing chamber: Boy, get me some tabacco, I'le but goe in, and shew I am here, and come to you presently, sir.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: What's that he said? by heauen, I markt him not:
My thoughts, and I, were of another world.
I was admiring mine owne out-side here,
To thinke what priuiledge, and palme it beares
Here, in the court! Be a man ne're so vile
In wit, in judgement, manners, or what else;
If he can purchase but a silken couer,
He shall not only passe, but passe regarded:
Whereas, let him be poore, and meanely clad,
Though ne're so richly parted; you shall haue
A fellow (that knowes nothing but his beefe,
Or how to rince his clammy guts in beere)
Will take him by the shoulders, or the throat,
And kicke him downe the staires. Such is the state
Of vertue, in bad clothes! ha, ha, ha, ha,
That raiment should be in such high request!
How long should I be, ere I should put off
To the lord Chancelors tombe, or the Shriues posts?
By heauen (I thinke) a thousand, thousand yeere.
His grauitie, his wisedome, and his faith,
To my dread Soueraigne (graces that suruiue him)
These I could well endure to reuerence,
But not his tombe: no more then I'ld commend
The chappell organ, for the guilt without,
Or this base violl, for the varnisht face.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: I feare I haue made you stay somewhat long, sir, but is my tabacco readie, boy?

sp.speaker: CINE.
sp.p: I, sir.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p:
Giue me, my mistris is vpon comming, you shall see her presently, sir, (Tab.) you'le say you neuer accosted a more piercing wit. This tabacco is not dryed, boy, or else the pipe's defectiue. Oh, your wits of
Italie are nothing comparable to her! her braine's a verie quiuer of iests! and she do's dart them abroad with that sweete loose, and iudiciall aime, that you would— here she comes sir.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.stage: She is seene and goes in againe.
sp.p: 'Twas time, his inuention had beene bogd else.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Giue me my fanne there.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: How now, Monsieur BRISKE?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: A kind of affectionate reuerence strikes mee with a cold shiuering (me thinkes.)

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: I like such tempers well, as stand before their mistresses with feare and trembling, and before their maker, like impudent mountaines.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: By this hand, I'ld spend twentie pound my vauting-horse stood here now, she might see me doe but one tricke?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Why, do's she loue actiuitie?

sp.speaker: CINE.
sp.p: Or if you had but your long stockings on, to be dancing a galliard, as she comes by.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: I eyther. O, these stirring humours make ladies mad with desire: shee comes. My good GENIVS embolden me, boy, the pipe quickly.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: What? will he giue her musicke?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: A second good morrow to my faire mistresse.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Faire seruant, I'le thanke you a day hence, when the date of your salutation comes forth.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: How, like you that answere? is't not admirable?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: I were a simple courtier, if I could not admire trifles, sir.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.stage: He talkes, and takes tabacco betweene.
sp.p: Troth, sweet ladie, I shall (Tab.) be prepar'd to giue you thanks for those thankes, and (Tab.) studie more officious, and obsequious regards (Tab.) to your faire beauties. (Tab.) mend the pipe, boy.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: I ne're knew tabacco taken as a parenthesis, before.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Fore god (sweete ladie) beleeue it, I doe honour the meanest rush in this chamber, for your loue.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: I, you need not tell mee that, sir, I doe thinke, you doe prize a rush, before my loue.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Is this the wonder of nations?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: O, by this ayre, pardon me, I said, for your loue, by this light: but it is the accustomed sharpnesse of your ingenuitie, sweete mistresse, to— Masse your violl's new strung, methinkes.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.stage: He takes downe the violl, and playes betweene.
sp.p: Ingenuitie. I see his ignorance will not suffer him to slander her, which he had done most notably, if he had said wit, for ingenuitie, as he meant it.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: By the soule of musicke, ladie (hum, hum.)

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Would we might heare it once.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: I doe more adore, and admire your (hum, hum) predominant perfections, then (hum, hum) euer I shall haue power, and facultie to expresse (hum.)

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Vpon the violl de Gambo, you meane?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: It's miserably out of tune, by this hand.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Nay, rather by the fingers.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: It makes good harmonie with her wit.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Sweet ladie, tune it. Boy, some tabacco.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Tabacco againe? he do's court his mistresse with verie exceeding good changes.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Signior MACILENTE, you take none, sir? (Tab.)

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: No, vnlesse I had a Mistresse, signior, it were a great indecorum for me to take tabacco.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: How like you her wit? (Tab.)

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Her ingenuitie is excellent, sir.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: You see the subiect of her sweet fingers, there? (Tab.) Oh, shee tickles it so, that (Tab.) shee makes it laugh most diuinely; (Tab.) I'le tell you a good iest now, and yourselfe shall say it's a good one: I haue wisht my selfe to be that instrument (I thinke) a thousand times, and not so few, by heauen (Tab.)

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Not vnlike, sir: but how? to be cas'd vp, and hung by on the wall?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: O, no, sir, to be in vse I assure you; as your iudicious eyes may testifie. (Tab.)

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Here, seruant, if you will play, come.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Instantly, sweet ladie. (Tab.) In good faith, here's most diuine tabacco!

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Nay, I cannot stay to dance after your pipe.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Good! nay, deare ladie, stay: by this sweete smoake, I thinke your wit be all fire. (Tab.)

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: And, hee's the Salamander belongs to it.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Is your tabacco perfum'd, seruant? that you sweare by the sweet smoke?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Still more excellent! (before heauen, and these bright lights) I thinke (Tab.) you are made of ingenuitie, I. (Tab.)

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: True, as your discourse is: Ô abominable!

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Will your ladiship take any?

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: O, peace I pray you; I loue not the breath of a woodcockes head.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Meaning my head, ladie?

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Not altogether so, sir; but (as it were fatall to their follies that thinke to grace themselues with taking tabacco, when they want better entertainment) you see your pipe beares the true forme of a woodcockes head.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: O admirable simile!

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: 'Tis best leauing of you in admiration, sir.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Are these the admired lady-wits, that hauing so good a plaine-song, can runne no better diuision vpon it? S'heart, all her iests are of the stampe, (March was fifteene yeres ago.) Is this the Comet, Monsieur FASTADIVS, that your gallants wonder at so?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Hart of a gentleman, to neglect mee afore presence thus! Sweet sir, I beseech you be silent in my disgrace. By the Muses, I was neuer in so vile a humour in my life, and her wit was at the cloud too. Report it not for a million, good sir; let me be so farre endear'd to your loue.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: What followes next, signior CORDATVS? this gallants humour is almost spent, me thinkes, it ebbes apace, with this contrarie breath of his mistresse.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: O, but it will blow againe for all this, till there come a generall drought of humour among all our actors, and then, I feare not but his wil fall as low as any. See, who presents himselfe here!

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: What, i'the old case?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Yfaith, which makes it, the more pittifull, you vnderstand where the Scene is?
WHy, are you so melancholy, brother?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I am not melancholy, I thanke you, sister.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Why are you not merrie then? there are but two of vs in all the world, and if wee should not bee comforts one to another, god helpe vs.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Faith, I cannot tell, sister, but if a man had any true melancholy in him, it would make him melancholy, to see his yeomanly father cut his neighbours throats, to make his sonne a gentleman: and yet when he has cut 'hem, he will see his sonnes throat cut too, ere he make him a true gentleman indeed, before death cut his owne throat. I must bee the first head of our house, and yet he will not giue me the head till I bee made so. Is any man term'd a gentleman that is not alwayes i'the fashion? I would know but that.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: If you bee melancholy for that, brother, I thinke I haue as much cause to bee melancholy, as one: for I'le be sworne, I liue as little in the fashion, as any woman in London. By the faith of a Gentlewoman, (beast that I am to say it) I ha'not one friend i'the world besides my husband. When saw you master FASTIDIVS BRISKE, brother?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: But a while since, sister, I thinke: I know not well in truth. By this hand, I could fight with all my heart, me thinkes.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Nay, good brother, be not resolute.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I sent him a letter, and he writes me no answere neyther.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p:
Oh, sweete FASTIDIVS BRISKE! Ô fine courtier! thou art hee mak'st me sigh, and say, how blessed is that woman that hath a courtier to her husband! and how miserable a dame shee is, that hath neyther
husband, nor friend i' the court! O, sweet FASTIDIVS! Ô, fine courtier! How comely he bowes him in his court'sie! how full hee hits a woman betweene the lips when hee kisses! how vpright hee sits at the table! how daintily he carues! how sweetly he talkes, and tels newes of this lord, and of that lady! how cleanely he wipes his spoone, at euery spoonfull of any whit-meat he eates, and what a neat case of pick-tooths he carries about him, still! O, sweet FASTIDIVS! Ô, fine courtier!
SEe, yonder shee is, gentlemen. Now (as euer you'll beare the name of musicians) touch your instruments sweetly, shee has a delicate eare, I tell you: play not a false note, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: MVSI.
sp.p: Feare not, siguior DELIRO.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: O, begin, begin, some sprightly thing: Lord, how my imagination labours with the successe of it. Well said, good yfaith! heauen grant it please her. I'le not be seene, for then shee'le be sure to dislike it.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Hey— da! this is excellent! I'le lay my life, this is my husbands dotage. I thought so; nay, neuer play peeke-boe with me, I know, you doe nothing but studie how to anger me, sir.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Anger thee, sweet wife? why didst thou not send for musicians to supper last night, thy selfe?

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: To supper, sir? now, come vp to supper, I beseech you: as though there were no difference between supper time, when folkes should be merry, and this time when they would be melancholy? I would neuer take vpon me to take a wife, if I had no more iudgement to please her.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Be pleas'd, sweet wife, and they shall ha' done: and would to fate, my life were done, if I can neuer please thee.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Saue you, lady, where is master DELIRO?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Here, master MACILENTE: you are welcome from court, sir; no doubt you haue beene grac't exceedingly of master BRISKES Mistris, and the rest of the ladies, for his sake?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: Alas, the poore phantasticke! hee's scarce knowne
To any lady there; and those that know him,
Know him the simplest man of all they know:
Deride, and play vpon his amorous humours,
Though he but apishly doth imitate
The gallant'st courtiers, kissing ladies pumps.
Holding the cloth for them, praising their wits,
And seruilely obseruing euery one,
May doe them pleasure: fearefull to be seene
With any man (though he be ne're so worthy)
That's not in grace with some, that are the greatest.
Thus courtiers doe, and these he counterfeits.
But sets not such a sightly carriage
Vpon their vanities, as they themselues;
And therefore they despise him: for indeed
Hee's like the Zani, to a tumbler,
That tries tricks after him, to make men laugh.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Here's an vnthankfull spitefull wretch! the good gentleman vouchsaft to make him his companion (because my husband put him into a few rags) and now see, how the vnrude rascall back-bites him!

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Is he no more grac't amongst 'hem, then? say you?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Faith, like a pawne, at Chesse: fills vp a roome, that's all.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: O monster of men! can the earth beare such an enuious caytiffe?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Well, I repent me, I e're credited him so much: but (now I see what he is, and that his masking vizor is off) I'le forbeare him no longer. All his lands are morgag'd to me, and forfeited: besides, I haue bonds of his in my hand, for the receit of now fifty pound, now a hundred, now two hundred: still, as he has had a fan but wagg'd at him, he would be in a new sute. Well, I'le salute him by a Sergeant, the next time I see him, yfaith, I'le sute him.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Why, you may soone see him, sir, for hee is to meet signior PVNTARVOLO at a Notaries, by the Exchange, presently: where he meanes to take vp, vpon returne—

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Now, out vpon thee, IVDAS; canst thou not be content to back-bite thy friend, but thou must betray him? wilt thou seeke the vndoing of any man? and of such a man too? and will you, sir, get your liuing by the counsell of traytors?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Deare wife, haue patience.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: The house will fall, the ground will open, and swallow vs: I'le not binde here, for all the gold, and siluer in heauen.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: O, good MACILENTE, let's follow and appease her, or the peace of my life is at an end.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Now pease, and not peace, feed that life, whose head bangs so heauily ouer a womans manger.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Helpe me, brother: 'ods body, and you come here, I'le doe my selfe a mischiefe.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Nay, heare me, sweet wife, vnlesse thou wilt haue mee goe, I will not goe.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p:
Tut, you shall ne're ha' that vantage of me, to say, you are vndone by me: I'le not bid you stay, I. Brother, sweet brother, here's foure angels, I'le giue you toward your sute: for the loue of gentry, and as euer you came of christen creature, make haste to the water fide (you know where Master FASTIDIVS vses to land) and giue him warning of my husbands malitious intent; & tel him of that leane rascals trechery: O heuens!
how my flesh rises at him! nay, sweet brother, make haste: you may say, I would haue writ to him, but that necessitie of the time would not permit. He cannot choose but take it extraordinarily from me: and commend me, to him, good brother, say, I sent you.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Let me see, these foure angels, and then, fortie shillings more I can borrow on my gowne in Fetter-lane. Well, I will goe presently, say on my sute, pay as much money as I haue, and sweare my selfe into credit with my taylor, for the rest.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.stage: Deliro, and Macilente, passe ouer the stage.
sp.l: O, on my soule you wrong her, MACILENTE,
Though shee be froward, yet I know shee is honest.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Well, then haue I no iudgement: would any woman (but one that were wild in her affections) haue broke out into that immodest and violent passion against her husband? or is't possible—

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: If you loue me, forbeare; all the arguments i' the world shall neuer wrest my heart to beleeue it.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: How like you the decyphering of his dotage?

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: O, strangely! and of the others enuie too, that labours so seriously to set debate betwixt a man, and his wife. Stay, here comes the knight aduenturer.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: I, and his scriuener with him.
I Wonder, Monsieur FASTIDIVS comes not! but, NOTARIE, if thou please to draw the indentures the while, I will giue thee thy instructions.

sp.speaker: NOTA.
sp.p: With all my heart, sir; and I'le fall in hand with 'hem presently.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Well then, first, the summe is to be vnderstood.

sp.speaker: NOTA.
sp.p: Good, sir.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Next, our seuerall appellations, and character of my dog, and cat, must be knowne: shew him the cat, sirrah.

sp.speaker: NOTA.
sp.p: So, sir.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Then, that the intended bound, is the Turkes court in Constantinople: the time limited for our returne, a yeere: and that if either of vs miscarry, the whole venter is lost. These are generall, conceiu'st thou? or if either of vs turne Turke.

sp.speaker: NOTA.
sp.p: I, sir.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Now for particulars: That I may make my trauails by sea or land, to my best liking: and that (hyring a coach for my selfe) it shall bee lawfull for my dog, or cat, or both, to ride with me in the said coach.

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: Very good, sir.

sp.speaker: PVN.
sp.p: That I may choose to giue my dogge, or cat fish, for feare of bones: or any other nutriment, that (by the iudgement of the most autenticall physicians, where I trauaile) shall be thought dangerous.

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: PVN.
sp.p: That (after the receit of his monie) he shall neyther in his own person, nor any other, eyther by direct or indirect meanes, as magicke, witchcraft, or other such exoticke artes, attempt, practise, or complot aniething, to the preiudice of mee, my dogge, or my cat: Neyther shall I vse the helpe of any such forceries, or enchantments, as vnctious, to make our skinnes impenetrable, or to trauaile inuisible by vertue of a powder, or a ring, or to hang any three-forked charme about my dogges necke, secretly conuey'd into his collar: (vnderstand you?) but that all be performed, sincerely, without fraud, or imposture.

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: So, sir.

sp.speaker: PVN.
sp.p: That (for testimonie of the performance) my selfe am to bring thence a Turkes mustachio, my dogge a Gracian hares lip, and my cat the traine, or taile of a Thracian rat.

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: 'Tis done, sir.

sp.speaker: PVN.
