sp.p: 'Tis said, sir, not done, sir: but forward. That vpon my returne, and landing on the Tower-wharfe, with the aforesaid testimonie, I am to receiue fiue for one, according to the proportion of the summes put forth.

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: PVN.
sp.p: Prouided, that if before our departure, or setting forth, either my selfe, or these be visited with sicknesse, or any other casuall euent, so that the whole course of the aduenture bee hindered, thereby; that then, he is to returne, and I am to receiue the prenominated proportion, vpon faire and equall termes.

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: Verie good, sir, is this all?

sp.speaker: PVN.
sp.p: It is all, sir: and dispatch them, good NOT ARIE.

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.p: As fast as is possible, sir.

sp.speaker: PVN.
sp.p: O, CARLO! welcome: saw you Monsieur BRISKE?

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Not I: did he appoint you, to meet here?

sp.speaker: PVN.
sp.p: I, and I muse he should be so tardie: hee is to take an hundred pounds of mee in venter, if he maintaine his promise.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Is his houre past?

sp.speaker: PVN.
sp.p: Not yet, but it comes on apace.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Tut, be not iealous of him: he will sooner breake all the commandements, then his houre, vpon my life, in such a case trust him.

sp.speaker: PVN.
sp.p: Me thinkes, CARLO, you looke verie smooth! ha?

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Why, I come but now from a hot-house, I must needes looke smooth.

sp.speaker: PVN.
sp.p: From a hot-house!

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p:
I, doo you make a wonder on't? why it's your only physicke.
Let a man sweate once a weeke in a hothouse, and be well rub'd, froted, with a good plumpe juicie wench, and sweet linnen: hee shall ne're ha' the poxe.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: What, the French poxe?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: The French poxe! our poxe. S'bloud we haue 'hem in as good forme as they, man: what?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Let mee perish, but thou art a salt one! was your new-created gallant there with you? SOGLIARDO?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: O, porpuse! hang him, no: hee's a lieger at Hornes ordinarie yonder: his villanous GANIMEDE, and he ha' beene droning a tabacco pipe there, euer sin' yesterday no one.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Who? signior TRIPARTITE, that would giue my dogge the Whiffe?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I, hee. They haue hir'd a chamber, and all priuate to practise in, for the making of the Patoun, the Receit reciprocall, and a number of other mysteries, not yet extant. I brought some dozen, or twentie gallants this morning to view 'hem (as you'ld doe a piece of Perspectiue) in at a key-hole: and there wee might see SOGLIARDO sit in a chaire, holding his snowt vp like a sow vnder an apple-tree, while th' other open'd his nostrils with a poking-sticke, to giue the smoke a more free deliuerie. They had spit some three, or fourescore ounces betweene 'hem, afore we came away.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: How! spit three, or fourescore ounces?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I, and preseru'd it in porrengers; as a barber does his bloud▪ when he opens a veine.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Out, Pagan: how dost thou open the veine of thy friend?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Friend? Is there any such foolish thing i'the world? ha? S'lid I ne're rellisht it yet.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Thy humour is the more dangerous.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: No, not a whit, Signior: Tut, a man must keepe time in all. I can oyle my tongue when I meet him next, and looke with a good slicke fore-head; 'twill take away all soyle of suspicion, and that's ynough: what LYNCEVS can see my heart? Pish, the title of a friend, it's a vaine idle thing, only venerable among fooles: you shall not haue one that has any opinion of wit affect it.
SAue you, good sir PVNTARVOLO.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Signior DELIRO! welcome.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Pray you, sir, did you see Master FASTIDIVS BRISKE? I heard he was to meet your worship here.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Your heard no sigment, sir, I doe expect him at euery pulse of my watch.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: In good time, sir.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: There's a fellow now, lookes like one of the Patricians of Sparta, mary his wit's after tenne i'the hundred. A good bloud-hound, a close-mouth'd dogge, he followes the sent well, mary he's at a fault now, me thinkes.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: I should wonder at that creature is free from the danger of thy tongue.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: O, I cannot abide these limmes of sattin, or rather Sathan indeed, that 'll walke (like the children of darknesse) all day in a melancholy shop, with their pockets full of blankes, readie to swallow vp as manie poore vnthrifts, as come within the verge.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: So! and what hast thou for him that is with him, now?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: O, (dam' mee) Immortalitie! I'le not meddle with him, the pure element of fire, all spirit, extraction.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: HOW, CARLO? ha, what is he, man?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: A scholler, MACILENTE, doe you not know him? a lanke raw-bon'd anatomie, he walkes vp and downe like a charg'd musket, no man dares encounter him: that's his rest there.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: His rest? why has he a forked head?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Pardon me, that's to be suspended, you are too quicke, too apprehensiue.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Troth (now I thinke on't) I'le deferre it till some other time.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Not, by any meanes, signior, you shall not lose this opportunitie, he will be here presently now.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Yes saith, MACILENTE, 'tis best. For looke you, sir, I shall so exceedingly offend my wife in't, that—

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Your wife? now for shame lose these thoughts, and become the master of your owne spirits. Should I (if I had a wife) suffer my selfe to be thus passionately carried (to and fro) with the streame of her humour? and neglect my deepest affaires, to serue her affections? S'light I would geld my selfe first.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: O but, signior, had you such a wife as mine is, you would—

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Such a wife? Now hate mee, sir, if euer I discern'd any wonder in your wife, yet, with all the speculation I haue: I haue seene some that ha' beene thought fairer then she, in my time; and I haue seene those, ha' not been altogether so tall, esteem'd properer women; and I haue seen lesse noses grow vpon sweeter faces, that haue done verie well too, in my iudgement: but in good faith, signior, for all this, the gentlewoman is a good pretie proud hard-fauour'd thing, mary not so peerelessely to bee doted vpon, I must confesse: nay, be not angrie.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Well, sir, (how euer you please to forget your selfe) I haue not deseru'd to bee thus plai'd vpon, but henceforth, pray you forbeare my house, for I can but faintly endure the fauour of his breath at my table, that shall thus iade me for my courtesies.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p:
Nay, then, signior, let me tell you, your wife is no proper woman,
and, by my life, I suspect her honestie, that's more, which you may likewise suspect (if you please:) doe you see? Ile vrge you to nothing, against your appetite, but if you please, you may suspect it.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Good, sir.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Good sir? Now horne vpon horne pursue thee, thou blinde egregious dotard.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: O, you shall heare him speake like ennie. Signior MACILENTE, you saw monsieur BRISKE lately? I heard you were with him at court.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: I, BVFFONE, I was with him.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: And how is he respected there? (I know youle deale ingenuously with vs) is he made of amongst the sweeter sort of gallants?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: Faith I, his ciuet and his casting-glasse,
Haue helpt him to a place amongst the rest:
And there, his Seniors giue him good sleight lookes,
After their garbe, smile, and salute in French
With some new complement.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.l: What, is this all?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: Why say, that they should shew the frothie foole,
Such grace, as they pretend comes from the heart,
He had a mightie wind-fall out of doubt.
Why, all their Graces are not to doe grace
To vertue, or desert: but to ride both
With their guilt sputres quite breathlesse, from themselues.
'Tis now esteem'd Precisianisme in wit;
And a disease in nature, to be kind
Toward desert, to loue, or seeke good names:
Who feeds with a good name? who thriues with louing?
Who can prouide feast for his owne desires,
With seruing others? ha, ha, ha:
'Tis folly, by our wisest worldlings prou'd,
(If not to gaine by loue) to be belou'd.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.l: How like you him? is't not a good spitefull slaue? ha?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.l: Shrewd, shrewd.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.l: Dam'me, I could eat his flesh now: diuine sweet villaine!

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: Nay, pr'y thee leaue: what's he there?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Who? this i'the starcht beard? it's the dull stiffe knight PVNTARVOLO, man; hee's to trauaile now presently: hee has a good knottie wit, marry he carries little o't out of the land, with him.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: He puts it forth in venter, as hee does his monie; vpon the returne of a dogge, and cat.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Is this he?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p:
I, this is hee; a good tough gentleman: hee lookes like a shield of brawne, at Shrouetide, out of date, and readie to take his leaue:
or a drie poule of ling vpon Easter-eue, that has furnisht the table all Lent, as he has done the citie this last vacation.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Come, you'le neuer leaue your stabbing smile's: I shall ha' you ayming at me with 'hem by and by, but—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: O, renounce me then: pure, honest, good deuill, I loue thee aboue the loue of women: I could e'en melt in admiration of thee, now! gods so, looke here, man; Sir DAGONET, and his squire!

SAue you, my deare GALLANTO'S: nay, come approch, good CAVALIER: pr'y thee (sweet knight) know this gentleman, hee's one that it pleases mee to vse as my good friend, and companion; and therefore doe him good offices: I beseech you, gentles, know him, know him all ouer.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Sir (for signior SOGLIARDO'S sake) let it suffice, I know you.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Why (as I am true gentleman) I thanke you, knight, and it shall suffice. Harke you, sir PVNTARVOLO, you'ld little thinke it; he's as resolute a peece of flesh, as any's i'the world.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Indeed, sir?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Vpon my gentilitie, sir: CARLO, a word with you; Doe you see that same fellow, there?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: What? CAVALIER SHIFT?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: O, you know him; crie you mercy: before me, I thinke him the tallest man, liuing within the walls of Europe.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: The walls of Europe! take heed what you say, signior, Europe's a huge thing within the walls.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Tut, (and 'twere as huge againe) I'ld iustifie what I speake. Slid, he swagger'd e'en now in a place where we were: I neuer saw a man doe it more resolute.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nay, indeede swaggering is a good argument of resolution. Doe you heare this, signior?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: I, to my griefe. O, that such muddy flags,
For euery drunken flourish, should atchieue
The name of manhood; whil'st true perfect valour
(Hating to shew it selfe) goes by despis'd!
Heart, I doe know now (in a faire iust cause)
I dare doe more then he, a thousand times:
Why should not they take knowledge of this? ha?
And giue my worth allowance before his?
Because I cannot swagger! Now the poxe
Light on your Pickt-hatch prowesse.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Why, I tell you, sir, he has beene the only Bid-stand that euer kept New-market, Salisbury-plaine, Hockley i'the hole, Gads-Hill; all the high places of any request: he has had his mares and his geldings, he, ha' been worth fortie, threescore, a hundred pound a horse, would ha' sprung you ouer hedge, and ditch, like your grey-hound, he has done fiue hundred robberies in his time, more or lesse, I assure you.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: What? and scapt?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Scapt! yfaith I: he has broken the jayle when he has beene in yrons, and yrons; and beene out, and in againe; and out, and in; fortie times, and not so few, he.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: A fit trumpet, to proclaime such a person.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: But can this be possible?

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Why, 'tis nothing, sir, when a man giues his affections to it.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Good PYLADES, discourse a robberie, or two, to satisfie these gentlemen of thy worth.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Pardon me, my deare ORESTES: Causes haue their quiddits, and 'tis ill iesting with bell-ropes.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: How? PYLADES, and ORESTES?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: I, he is my PYLADES, and I am his ORESTES: how like you the conceit?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: O, it's an old stale enterlude deuice: No, I'le giue you names my selfe, looke you, he shall be your IVDAS, and you shall bee his Elder tree, to hang on.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Nay, rather, let him be captaine POD, and this his Motion; for he does nothing but shew him.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Excellent: or thus, you shall bee HOLDEN, and hee your Camel.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: You doe not meane to ride, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Faith, let me end it for you, gallants: you shall be his Countenance, and he your Resolution.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Troth, that's pretty: how say you, Caualier, shalt be so?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I, I, most voices.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Faith, I am easily yeelding to any good impressions.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Then giue hands, good Resolution.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Masse, he cannot say, good Countenance, now (properly) to him againe.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Yes, by an irony.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: O, sir, the countenance of Resolution should, as he is, be altogether grim, and vnpleasant.

sp.speaker: FASTIDIVS BRISKE.
sp.p: GOod houres make musicke with your mirth, gentlemen, and keepe time to your humours: how now, CARLO?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Monsieur BRISKE! many a long looke haue I extended for you, sir.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Good faith, I must craue pardon; I was inuited this morning ere I was out of my bed, by a beuie of ladies, to a banquet: whence it was almost one of HERCVLES labours for me, to come away, but that the respect of my promise did so preuaile with me: I know they'le take it very ill, especially one that gaue me this bracelet of her haire but ouer-night, and this pearle another gaue me from her fore-head, mary, shee— what? are the writings ready?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: I will send my man to know. Sirrah, goe you to the Notaries, and learne if he be readie: leaue the dog, sir.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: And how does my rare qualified friend, SOGLIARDO? oh, signior MACILENTE! by these eyes, I saw you not, I had saluted you sooner else, o'my troth: I hope, sir, I may presume vpon you, that you will not diuulge my late checke, or disgrace, indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: You may, sir.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: S'heart, he knowes some notorious iest by this gull, that hee hath him so obsequious.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Monsieur FASTIDIVS, doe you see this fellow there? does he not looke like a clowne? would you thinke there's any thing in him?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Anything in him? beshrow me, I; the fellow hath a good ingenious face.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: By this element, he is an ingenious tall man, as euer swagger'd about London: he, and I, call Countenance, and Resolution, but his name is CAVALIER SHIFT.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: CAVALIER, you knew signior CLOG, that was hang'd for the robbery at Harrow o'the hill?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Knew him, sir! why, 'twas hee gaue all the directions for the action.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: How? was't your proiect, sir?

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Pardon me, Countenance, you doe me some wrong to make that publike, which I imparted to you in priuate.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Gods will! here are none but friends, Resolution.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p:
That's all one; things of consequence must haue their respects, where, how, and to whom. Yes, sir, hee shewed himselfe a true CLOG in the coherence of that affaire, sir; for if he had manag'd matters as they were corroborated to him, it had beene better for him by a fortie, or fiftie score of pounds, sir, and he himselfe might ha' liu'd (in despight
of fates) to haue fed on wood-cocks, with the rest: but it was his heauie fortune to sinke, poore CLOG, and therefore talke no more of him.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Why, had he more aiders, then?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: O god, sir! I, there were some present there, that were the nine Worthies to him, yfaith.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: I, sir, I can satisfie you at more conuenient conference: but (for mine owne part) I haue now reconcil'd my selfe to other courses, and professe a liuing out of my other qualities.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Nay, he has left all now (I assure you) and is able to liue like a gentleman, by his quality. By this dogge, hee has the most rare gift in tabacco, that euer you knew.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: S'heart, hee keepes more adoe with this monster, then euer BANKES did with his horse, or the fellow with the elephant.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: He will hang out his picture shortly, in a cloth, you shall see.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: O, hee do's manage a quarrell, the best that euer you saw, for termes, and circumstances.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Good faith, signior, (now you speake of a quarrell) I'le acquaint you with a difference, that happened betweene a gallant, and my selfe sir PVNTARVOLO, you know him if I should name him, signior LVCVLENTO.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: LVCVLENTO! what in-auspicious chance interpos'd it selfe to your two loues?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Faith, sir, the same that sundred AGAMEMNON, and great THETIS sonne; but let the cause escape, sir: Hee sent mee a challenge (mict with some few braues) which I restor'd, and in fine we met. Now indeed, sir, (I must tell you) he did offer at first very desperately, but without iudgement: for looke you, sir. I cast my selfe into this figure: now he, comes violently on, and withall aduancing his rapier to strike, I thought to haue tooke his arme (for he had left his whole body to my election, and I was sure he could not recouer his guard) Sir, I mist my purpose in his arme, rasht his doublet sleeue, ran him close by the left cheek, and through his haire. He againe, lights me here (I had on, a gold cable hatband, then new come vp, which I wore about a murrey French hat I had) cuts my hatband (and yet it was massie, gold-smithes worke) cuts my brimmes, which by good fortune (being thicke embrodered with gold-twist, and spangles) disappointed the force of the blow: Neuerthelesse, it graz'd on my shoulder, takes me away sixe purles of an Italian cut-worke band I wore (cost me three pound in the exchange, but three daies before.)

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: This was a strange encounter!

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p:
Nay, you shall heare, sir: with this wee both fell out, and breath'd. Now (vpon the second signe of his assault) I betooke me to the former manner of my defence; he (on the other side) abandon'd his body to the same danger, as before, and followes me still with blowes: But I (being loth to take the deadly aduantage that lay before mee of his left side) made a kind of stramazoun, ranne him vp to the hilts, through the
doublet, through the shirt, and yet mist the skin. Hee (making a reuerse blow) falls vpon my emboss'd girdle (I had throwne off the hangers a little before) strikes off a skirt of a thick— lac't sattin doublet I had (lin'd with some foure taffataes) cuts off two panes, embrodered with pearle, rends through the drawings out of tissew, enters the linings, and skips the flesh.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I wonder he speakes not of his wrought shirt!

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Here (in the opinion of mutuall dammage) wee paus'd: but (ere I proceed) I must tell you, signior, that (in this last encounter) not hauing leisure to put off my siluer spurres, one of the rowels catcht hold of the ruffle of my boot, and (being Spanish leather, and subiect to teare) ouerthrowes me, rends me two paire of silke stockings (that I put on, being somewhat a raw morning, a peach colour and another) and strikes me some halfe inch deepe into the side of the calfe; Hee (seeing the bloud come) presently takes horse, and away. I (hauing bound vp my wound with a peece of my wrought shirt)—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: O! comes it in there?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Rid after him, and (lighting at the court-gate, both together) embrac'd, and marcht hand in hand vp into the presence: was not this businesse well carried?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Well? yes, and by this we can gesse what apparell the gentleman wore.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Fore valour, it was a designement begun with much resolution, maintain'd with as much prowesse, and ended with more humanitie. How now, what saies the Notarie?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: He saies, he is ready, sir, he staies but your worships pleasure.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Come, we will goe to him, Monsieur. Gentlemen, shall we entreat you to be witnesses?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: You shall entreat me, sir: come Resolution.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: I follow you, good Countenance.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Come, signior, come, come.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.l: O, that there should be fortune
To clothe these men, so naked in desert!
And that the iust storme of a wretched life,
Beats 'hem not ragged, for their wretched soules,
And, since as fruitlesse, euen as black as coales!

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: Why, but signior, how comes it, that FVNGOSO appear'd not with his sisters intelligence, to BRISKE?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Mary, long of the euill angels that she gaue him, who haue indeed tempted the good simple youth, to follow the taile of the fashion, and neglect the imposition of his friends. Behold, here hee comes, very worshipfully attended and with good varietie.
GRamercie, good shoo-maker, I'le put to strings my selfe. Now, sir, let me see, what must you haue for this hat?

sp.speaker: HABER.
sp.p: Here's the bill, sir.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: How does't become me? well?

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: Excellent, sir, as euer you had any hat in your life.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Nay, you'll say so, all.

sp.speaker: HABE.
sp.p: In faith, sir, the hat's as good as any man i' this towne can serue you; and will maintayne fashion as long: ne're trust me for a groat else.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Do's it apply well to my sute?

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: Exceeding well, sir.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: How lik'st thou my sute, haberdasher?

sp.speaker: HABE.
sp.p: By my troth, sir, 'tis very rarely well made, I neuer saw a sute sit better, I can tell, on.

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: Nay, we haue no arte to please our friends, we.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Here, haberdasher, tell this fame.

sp.speaker: HABE.
sp.p: Good faith, sir, it makes you haue an excellent body.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Nay (beleeue me) I thinke I haue as good a body in clothes, as another.

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: You lack points, to bring your apparell together, sir.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I'le haue points anon: how now? is't right?

sp.speaker: HABE.
sp.p: Faith, sir, 'tis too little, but vpon farther hopes— Good morrow to you, sir.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Farewell, good haberdasher. Well, now master SNIP, let mee see your bill.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: Me thinkes he discharges his followers too thicke.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: O, therein he fancily imitates some great man. I warrant you, though he turnes off them, he keepes this taylor, in place of a page, to follow him still.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: This bill is very reasonable, in faith (harke you, master SNIP) Troth, sir, I am not altogether so well furnisht at this present, as I could wish I were, but— If you'le doe mee the fauour to take part in hand, you shall haue all I haue, by this hand—

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: And, but giue mee credit for the rest, till the beginning of the next terme.

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: O lord, sir—

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p:
Fore god, and by this light, I'le pay you to the vtmost, and
acknowledge my selfe verie deeply engag'd to you, by the courtesie.

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: Why, how much haue you there, sir?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Mary I haue here foure angels, and fifteene shillings of white monie: it's all I haue, as I hope to be blest.

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: You will not faile me, at the next tearme, with the rest.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: No, and I doe, pray heauen, I be hang'd. Let me neuer breathe againe, vpon this mortall stage, as the philosopher cals it. By this aire, and (as I am a gentleman) I'le hold.

sp.speaker: CORD.
sp.p: He were an yron-hearted fellow, in my iudgement, that would not credit him vpon this volley of othes.

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: Well, sir, I'le not sticke with any gentleman for a trifle: you know what 'tis, remaines?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I, sir, and I giue you thankes in good faith. O fate! how happie am I made in this good fortune! Well, now I'le goe seeke out Monsieur BRISKE. 'Ods so, I haue forgot ribband for my shooes, and points. Slid, what lucke 's this! how shall I doe? Master SNIPPE, pray let me reduct some two or three shillings for points, and ribband: as I am an honest man, I haue vtterly disfurnisht my selfe, in the default of memorie, pray'le me be beholding to you, it shall come home i'the bill, beleeue me.

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: Faith, sir, I can hardly depart with ready mony, but I'le take vp, and send you some by my boy, presently. What colour'd ribband would you haue?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: What you shall thinke meet i'your iudgement, sir, to my sute.

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: Well, I'le send you some presently.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: And points too, sir?

sp.speaker: TAIL.
sp.p: And points too, sir.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Good lord! how shall I studie to deserue this kindnesse of you, sir? Pray, let your youth make haste, for I should haue done a businesse an houre since, that I doubt I shall come too late. Now, in good faith, I am exceeding proud of my sute.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Doe you obserue the plunges, that this poore gallant is put to (signior) to purchase the fashion?

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: I, and to bee still a fashion behinde with the world, that's the sport.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Stay: O here they come, from seal'd, and deliuer'd.

div.head: Act IIII. Scene VIII.
div.stage: PVNTARVOLO, FASTIDIVS BRISKE, SERVANTS CARLO, SOGLIARDO, MACILENTE, SHIFT. FVNGOSO.

sp.p: WEll, now my whole venter is forth, I will resolue to depart shortly.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Faith, sir PVNTARVOLO, goe to the court, and take leaue of the ladies first.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: I care not, if it be this afternoones labour. Where is CARLO?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Here he comes.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Faith, gallants, I am perswading this gentleman to turne courtier. He is a man of faire reuenue, and his estate will beare the charge well. Besides, for his other gifts of the minde, or so, why, they are as nature lent him 'hem, pure, simple, without any artificiall drug or mixture of these two thred-bare beggarly qualities, learning, and knowledge, and therefore the more accommodate, and genuine. Now, for the life it selfe—

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: O, the most celestiall, and full of wonder, and delight, that can be imagin'd, signior, beyond all thought, and apprehension of pleasure! A man liues there, in that diuine rapture, that hee will thinke himselfe i'the ninth heauen for the time, and lose all sense of mortalitie whatsoeuer; when he shall behold such glorious (and almost immortall) beauties, heare such angelicall and harmonious voyces, discourse with such flowing and ambrosiam spirits, whose wits are as suddaine as lightning, and humorous as nectar, Oh: it makes a man al quintessence, and flame, & lifts him vp (in a moment) to the verie christall crowne of the skie, where (houering in the strength of his imagination) he shall behold all the delights of the HESPERIDES, the Insulae Fortunatae, ADONIS gardens, Tempe or what else (condfin'd within the amplest verge of poesie) to bee meere vmbrae, and imperfect figures, conferr'd with the most essentiall felicitie of your court.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Well, this Encomion was not extemporall, it came too perfectly off.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Besides, sir, you shall neuer need to goe to a hot-house, you shall sweat there with courting your mistresse, or losing your monie at primero, as well as in all the stones in Sweden. Mary this, sir, you must euer be sure to carrie a good strong perfume about you, that your mistresse dogge may smell you out amongst the rest; and (in making loue to her) neuer feare to be out: for you may haue a pipe of tabacco, or a base violl shall hang o'the wall, of purpose, will put you in presently. The trickes your Resolution has taught you in tabacco, (the whisse, and those sleights) will stand you in verie good ornament there?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: I, to some perhaps: but, and hee should come to my mistresse with tabacco (this gentleman knowes) shee'ld reply vpon him, yfaith. O, (by this bright sunne) shee has the most acute, readie, and facetious wit, that— tut there's no spirit able to stand her. You can report it, signior, you haue seene her?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Then can hee report no lesse, out of his iudgement, I assure him.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Troth, I like her well enough, but shee's too selfe-conceited, me thinkes.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: I indeed, shee's a little too selfe conceited, and 'twere not for that humour, she were the most-to-be-admir'd ladie in the world.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Indeed, it is a humour that takes from her other excellencies.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Why, it may easily be made to forsake her, in my thought.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Easily, sir? then are all impossibilities easie.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: You conclude too quicke vpon me, signior, what will you say, if I make it so perspicuously appeare now, that your selfe shall confesse nothing more possible?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Mary, I will say, I will both applaud, and admire you for it.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: And I will second him, in the admiration.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Why, I'le shew you, gentlemen. CARLO, come hither.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Good faith, I haue a great humor to the court: what thinkes my Resolution? shall I aduenture?

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Troth, Countenance, as you please; the place is a place of good reputation, and capacitie.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: O, my trickes in tabacco (as CARLO sayes) will shew excellent there.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Why, you may goe with these gentlemen now, and see fashions: and after, as you shall see correspondence.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: You say true. You will goe with me, Resolution?

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: I will meet you, Countenance, about three or foure of clocke, but, to say to goe with you I cannot, for (as I am APPLE-IOHN) I am to goe before the Cocatrice you saw this morning, and therefore pray', present mee excus'd, good Countenance.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Farewell, good Resolution, but faile not to meet.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: As I liue.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Admirably excellent!

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: If you can but perswade SOGLIARDO to court, there's all now.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: O let me alone, that's my taske.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Now, by wit, MACILENTE, it's aboue measure excellent: 'twill be the onely court-exploit that euer prou'd courtier ingenious.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Vpon my soule, it puts the ladie quite out of her humour, and we shall laugh with iudgement.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Come, the gentleman was of himselfe resolu'd to goe with you, afore I mou'd it.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p:
Why then, gallants, you two, and CARLO, goe afore to
prepare the iest: SOGLIARDO and I will come some while after you.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Pardon me, I am not for court.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: That's true: CARLO comes not at court indeed. Well, you shall leaue it to the facultie of monsieur BRISKE, and my selfe, vpon our liues wee will manage it happily. CARLO shall bespeake supper, at the miter, against we come backe: where we will meet, and dimple our cheekes with laughter at the successe.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I, but will you all promise to come?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: My selfe shall manfrede it for them: he that failes, let his reputation lye vnder the lash of thy tongue.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Gods so, looke who comes here!

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: What, nephew!

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Vncle, god saue you; did you see a gentleman, one monsieur BRISKE? a Courtier, he goes in such a sute as I doe.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Here is the gentleman, nephew, but not in such a sute.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Another sute!

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: How now, nephew?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Would you speake to me, sir?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I, when he has recouered himselfe: poore poll.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Some Rosa-solis.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: How now, signior?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I am not well, sir.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Why, this it is, to dogge the fashion.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nay, come gentlemen, remember your affaires; his disease is nothing but the fluxe of apparell.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Sirs, returne to the lodging, keepe the cat safe; I'le be the dogs Guardian my selfe.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Nephew, will you goe to court with vs? these gentlemen and I are for the court: nay, be not so melancholy.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: By gods lid, I thinke no man in christendome has that rascally fortune that I haue.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Faith, your sute is well enough, signior.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Nay, not for that, I protest; but I had an errand to Monsieur FASTIDIVS, and I haue forgot it.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Why, goe along to court with vs, and remember it, come. Gentlemen, you three take one boat, and SOGLIARDO and I will take another: we shall be there instantly.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Content: good sir, vouchsafe vs your pleasance.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Farewell, CARLO; remember.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I warrant you: would I had one of Kemps shooes to throw after you.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Good Fortune will close the eyes of our iest, feare not: and we shall frollicke.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: This MACILENTE, signior, begins to bee more sociable on a suddaine, mee thinkes, then hee was before: there's some portent in't, I beleeue.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: O, hee's a fellow of a strange nature. Now do's hee (in this calme of his humour) plot, and store vp a world of malicious thoughts in his braine, till hee is so full with 'hem, that you shall see the very torrent of his enuie breake forth like a land-floud: and, against the course of all their affections oppose it selfe so violently, that you will almost haue wonder to thinke, how 'tis possible the current of their dispositions shall receiue so quick, and strong an alteration.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: I mary, sir, this is that, on which my expectation has dwelt al this while: for I must tel you, signior (though I was loth to interrupt the Scene) yet I made it a question in mine owne priuate discourse, how he should properly call it, Euery man out of his Humour, when I saw all his actors so strongly pursue, and continue their humours?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Why, therein his art appeares most full of lustre, and approcheth neerest the life: especially, when in the flame, and height of their humours, they are laid flat, it fils the eye better, and with more contentment. How tedious a sight were it to behold a proud exalted tree lopt, and cut downe by degrees, when it might bee feld in a moment? and to set the axe to it before it came to that pride, and fulnesse, were, as not to haue it grow.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: Well, I shall long till I see this fall, you talke of.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: To helpe your longing, signior, let your imagination be swifter them a paire of oares: and by this, suppose PVNTARVOLO, BRISKE, FVNGOSO, and the dogge arriu'd at the court gate, and going vp to the great chamber. MACILENTE, and SOGLIARDO, wee'le leaue them on the water, till possibilitie and naturall meanes may land 'hem. Here come the gallants, now prepare your expectation.

div.head: Scene I.
div.stage: PVNTARVOLO, FASTIDIVS BRISKE, FVNGOSO, GROOME, MACILENTE, SOGLIARDO.

sp.p: COme, gentles. Signior, you are sufficiently instructed.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Who, I, sir?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: No, this gentleman. But stay, I take thought how to bestow my dogge, he is no competent attendant for the presence.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Masse, that's true indeed, knight, you must not carrie him into the presence.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: I know it, and I (like a dull beast) forgot to bring one of my cormorants to attend me.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Why, you're best leaue him at the porters lodge.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Not so: his worth is too well knowne amongst them, to bee forth-comming.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Slight, how'll you doe then?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: I must leaue him with one, that is ignorant of his qualitie, if I will haue him to be safe. And see! Here comes one that wil carrie coales, ergo, will hold my dogge. My honest friend, may I commit the tuition of this dogge to thy prudent care?

sp.speaker: GROO.
sp.p: You may, if you please, sir.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Pray thee let me find thee here at my returne: it shall not bee long, till I will ease thee of thy imployment, and please thee. Forth, gentles.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Why, but will you leaue him with so slight command, and infirse no more charge, vpon the fellow?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Charge? no; there were no policie in that: that were to let him know the value of the gemme he holds, and so, to tempt fraile nature against her disposition. No, pray thee let thy honestie be sweet, as it shall be short.

sp.speaker: GROO.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: But harke you gallants, and chiefely Monsieur BRISKE. When we come in eye-shot, or presence of this ladie, let not other matters carrie vs from our proiect: but (if wee can) single her forth to some place—

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: And bee not too suddaine, but let the deuice induce it selfe with good circumstance. On.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Is this the way? good truth, here be fine hangings.

sp.speaker: GROO.
sp.p: Honestie sweet, and short? mary it shall, sir, doubt you not: for euen at this instant if one would giue mee twentie pounds, I would not deliuer him; there's for the sweet; but now, if any man come offer me but two pence, he shall haue him; there's for the short now. Slid, what a mad humorous gentleman is this to leaue his dogge with me? I could run away with him now, and hee were worth any thing.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Come on, signior, now prepare to court this all-witted ladie, most naturally, and like your selfe.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Faith, and you say the word, I'le begin to her in tabacco.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: O, fie on't: no: you shall begin with, How does my sweet ladie? or, Why are you so melancholy, Madame? though shee bee verie merrie, it's all one: be sure to kisse your hand often inough; pray for her health, and tell her, how, more then most faire she is. Screw your face at one side thus, and protest; let her fleere, and looke a skaunce, and hide her teeth with her fanne, when she laughs a fit, to bring her into more matter, that's nothing: you must talke forward (though it be without sense, so it be without blushing) 'tis most court-like, and well.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: But shall I not vse tabacco at all?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: O, by no meanes, 'twill but make your breath suspected, and that you vse it onely to confound the rankenesse of that.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Nay, I'le be aduis'd, sir, by my friends.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Gods my life, see, where sir PVNTARS dog is.

sp.speaker: GROO.
sp.p: I would the gentleman would returne for his follower here, I'le leaue him to his fortunes else.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: S'heart, 'twere the onely true iest in the world to poison him now: ha? by this hand, I'le doe it, if I could but get him of the fellow. Signior SOGLIARDO, walke aside, and thinke vpon some deuice, to entertaine the ladie with.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: So I doe, sir.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: How now, mine honest friend? whose dog-keeper art thou?

sp.speaker: GROO.
sp.p: Dogge-keeper, sir? I hope I scorne that yfaith.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Why? do'st thou not keepe a dogge?

sp.speaker: GROO.
sp.p: Sir, now I doe, and now I doe not: I thinke this be sweet and short. Make me his dogge-keeper?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: This is excellent, aboue expectation: nay stay, sir, you'ld bee trauailing, but I'le giue you a dramme shall shorten your voyage: here. So sir, I'le be bold to take my leaue of you. Now to the Turkes court in the deuils name, for you shall neuer goe o'gods name. SOGLIARDO, come.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: I ha' 't ysaith now, will sting it.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Take heed you leese it not, signior, ere you come there: preserue it.

sp.speaker: CORD.
sp.p: How like you this first exploit of his?

sp.speaker: MITIS.
sp.p: O, a piece of true enuie: but I expect the issue of the other deuice.

sp.speaker: CORD.
sp.p: Here they come, will make it appeare.

div.head: Act V. Scene II.
div.stage: SAVIOLINA, PVNTARVOLO, FASTIDIVS BRISKE, FVNGOSO, MACILENTE, SOGLIARDO.

sp.p: WHy, I thought, sir PVNTARVOLO, you had bin gone your voyage?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Deare, and most amiable ladie, your diuine beauties doe bind me to those offices, that I cannot depart when I would.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: 'Tis most court-like spoken, sir: but how might we do to haue a sight of your dogge, and cat?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: His dogge is in the court, ladie.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: And not your cat? how dare you trust her behind you, sir?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p:
Troth, madame, shee hath sore eyes, and shee doth keepe her
chamber: mary I haue left vnder sufficient guard, there are two of my followers to attend her.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: I'le giue you some water for her eyes: when doe you goe, sir?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Certes, sweet ladie, I know not.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: He doth stay the rather, madame, to present you acute iudgement with so courtly, and wel-parted a gentleman, as yet your lady-ship hath neuer seene.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: What's hee, gentle Monsieur BRISKE? not that gentleman?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: No ladie, this is a kinsman to iustice Silence.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Pray' sir, giue me leaue to report him: he's a gentleman (ladie) of that rare and admirable facultie, as (I protest) I know not his like in Europe: hee is exceedingly valiant, an excellent scholler, and so exactly trauail'd, that hee is able in discourse, to deliuer you a modell of any princes court in the world: speakes the languages with that puritie of phrase, and facilitie of accent, that it breeds astonishment: his wit, the most exuberant, and (aboue wonder) pleasant, of all that euer entred the concaue of this eue.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: 'Tis most true, ladie: mary, he is no such excellent proper man.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: His trauailes haue chang'd his complexion, madame.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: O, sir PVNTARVOLO, you must thinke, euery man was not borne to haue my seruant BRISKES feature.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: But that which transcends all, ladie; hee doth so peerelessely imitate any manner of person for gesture, action, passion, or whateuer—

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: I, especially a rusticke, or a clowne, madame, that it is not possible for the sharpest-sighted wit (in the world) to discerne any sparkes of the gentleman in him, when he does.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: O, Monsieur BRISKE, be not so tyrannous to confine all wits within the compasse of your owne: not find the sparkes of a gentleman in him, if he be a gentleman?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: No in truth (sweet ladie) I beleeue you cannot.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Doe you beleeue so? why, I can find sparkes of a gentleman in you, sir.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: I, he is a gentleman, madame, and a reueller.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Indeed, I thinke I haue seene your ladiship at our reuels.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Like enough, sir: but would I might see this wonder you talke of: may one haue a sight of him, for any reasonable summe?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Yes, madame, he will arriue presently.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: What, and shall we see him clowne it?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: I faith (sweet ladie) that you shall: see, here he comes.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: This is he! pray obserue him, ladie.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Be shrew me, he clownes it properly indeed.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Nay, marke his courtship.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: How does my sweet ladie? hote, and moyst? beautifull and lustie? ha?

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Beautifull, and it please you, sir, but not lustie.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: O ho, ladie; it pleases you to say so in truth: and how does my sweet ladie? in health? Bonaroba, quaeso, que nouelles? que nouells? sweet creature.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: O excellent: why gallants, is this hee that cannot bee decipher'd? they were verie bleare-witted, yfaith, that could not discerne the gentleman in him.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: But, doe you, in earnest, ladie?

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Doe I, sir? why, if you had any true court-iudgement in the carriage of his eye, and that inward power that formes his countenance, you might perceiue his counterfeiting as cleere, as the noone-day: Alas— Nay, if you would haue tryed my wit, indeed, you should neuer haue told me he was a gentleman, but presented him for a true clowne indeede; and then haue seene if I could haue decipher'd him.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Fore god, her ladiship sayes true (knight:) but does he not affect the clowne most naturally, mistresse?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: O, shee cannot but affirme that, out of the bountie of her iudgement.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Nay, out of doubt hee does well, for a gentleman, to imitate; but I warrant you, he becomes his natural carriage of the gentleman, much better then his clownerie.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: 'Tis strange, in truth, her ladiship should see so farre into him.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: I, is't not?

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Faith, as easily as may be: not decipher him, quoth you?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Good sadnesse, I wonder at it!

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Why, has she decipher'd him, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: O, most miraculously, and beyond admiration!

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Shee hath gather'd most infallible signes of the gentleman in him, that's certaine.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Why, gallants, let mee laugh at you, a little: was this your deuice, to trie my iudgement in a gentleman?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Nay, ladie, doe not scorne vs, though you haue this gift of perspicacie aboue others: What if hee should bee no gentleman now, but a clowne indeed, ladie?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: How thinke you of that? would not your ladiship bee out of your humour?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: O, but shee knowes it is not so.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: What if he were not a man, yee may as well say? nay, if your worships could gull me so, indeed, you were wiser then you are taken for.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: In good faith, ladie, hee is a verie perfect clowne, both by father, and mother: that I'le assure you.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: O, sir, you are verie pleasurable.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Nay, doe but looke on his hand, and that shall resolue you: looke you, ladie, what a palme here is.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Tut, that was with holding the plough.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: The plough! did you discerne any such thing in him, madame?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Faith no, she saw the gentleman as bright, as at noon-day, she: shee decipher'd him at first.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Troth, I am sorrie your ladiships sight should be so suddainly strooke.

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: O, you're goodly beagles!

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: What, is she gone?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Nay, stay, sweet ladie, que nouelles? que nouelles?

sp.speaker: SAVI.
sp.p: Out, you foole, you.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Shee's out of her humour yfaith.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Nay, let's follow it while 'tis hot, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Come, on mine honour wee shall make her blush in the presence: my splene is great with laughter.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Your laughter wil be a child of a feeble life, I beleeue, sir. Come, signior, your lookes are too deiected, mee thinkes: why mixe you not mirth with the rest?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: By gods will, this sute frets me at the soule. I'le haue it alter'd to morrow, sure.

div.head: Act V. scene III.
div.stage: SHIFT. FASTIDIVS, PVNTARVOLO, SOGLIARDO, FVNGOSO, MACILENTE.

sp.p: I Am come to the court, to meet with my Countenance SOGLIARDO: poore men must be glad of such countenance, when they can get no better. Wel. Need may insult vpon a man, but it shal neuer make him despaire of consequence. The world wil say, tis base: tush, base! 'tis base to liue vnder the earth, not base to liue aboue it, by any meanes.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: The poore ladie is most miserably out of her humour, yfaith.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: There was neuer so wittie a iest broken, at the tilt of all the court-wits christen'd.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: O, this applause taints it, fouly.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: I thinke, I did my part in courting. O! Resolution!

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Aye me, my dogge.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Where is hee?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Gods precious, goe seeke for the fellow, good signior.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Here, here I left him.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Why, none was here when we came in now, but CAVALIER SHIFT, enquire of him.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Did you see sir PVNTARVOLO'S dogge here, Caualier, since you came?

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: His dog sir? he may looke his dog, sir, I saw none of his dog, sir.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Vpon my life, he hath stol'ne your dogge, sir, and beene hir'd to it by some that haue ventur'd with you: you may gesse by his peremptorie answeres.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Not vnlike; for he hath beene a notorious thiefe by his owne confession. Sirrah, where is my dogge?

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Charge mee with your dogge, sir? I ha' none of your dog, sir.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Villaine, thou lyest.

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Lie, sir? S'bloud, y' are but a man, sir.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Rogue, and thiefe, restore him.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Take heed, sir PVNTARVOLO, what you doe: heele beare no coales, I can tell you (o' my word.)

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: This is rare.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: It's mar'le hee stabs you not: by this light, he hath stab'd forty, for forty times lesse matter, I can tell you, of my knowledge.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: I wil make thee stoope, thou abiect.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Make him stoop, sir! gentlemen, pacifie him or hee'le be kill'd.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Is he so tall a man?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Tall a man? if you loue his life, stand betwixt 'hem: make him stoope!

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: My dogge, villaine, or I will hang thee: thou hast confest robberies, and other fellonious acts, to this gentleman thy Countenance—

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: I'le beare no witnesse.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: And, without my dogge, I will hang thee, for them.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: What? kneele to thine enemies?

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: Pardon me, good sir; god is my witnesse, I neuer did robberie in all my life.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: O, sir PVNTARVOLO, your dogge lies giuing vp the ghost in the wood-yard.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Heart! is he not dead, yet?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: O, my dog, born to disastrous fortune! pray you conduct me, sir.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: How? did you neuer doe any robberie, in your life?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: O, this is good: so he swore, sir.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: I, I heard him. And did you sweare true, sir?

sp.speaker: SHIFT.
sp.p: I, (as I hope to be forgiuen, sir) I ne're rob'd any man, I neuer stood by the high-way-side, sir, but only said so, because I would get my selfe a name, and be counted a tall man.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Now out, base viliaco: Thou my Resolution? I thy Countenance? By this light, gentlemen, he hath confest to mee the most inexorable companie of robberies, and damn'd himselfe that he did 'hem; you neuer heard the like: out skoundrell, out, follow me no more, I commaund thee: out of my sight, goe, hence, speake not: I wil not heare thee: away camouccio.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p:
O, how I doe feed vpon this now, and fat my selfe! here were a couple vnexpectedly dishumour'd: well, by this time, I hope, sir PVNTARVOLO and his dog are both out of humour to trauaile. Nay, gentlemen,
why doe you not seeke out the knight, and comfort him? our supper at the Mitre must of necessitie hold to night, if you loue your reputations.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: 'Fore god, I am so melancholy for his dogs disaster, but I'le goe.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Faith, and I may goe too, but I know, I shall be so melancholy.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Tush, melancholy? you must forget that now, and remember you lie at the mercy of a furie: CARLO will racke your sinewes asunder, and raile you to dust, if you come not.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: O, then their feare of CARLO, belike, makes them hold their meeting.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: I, here he comes: conceiue him but to be enter'd the Mitre, and 'tis enough.
HOlla: where be these shot-sharkes?

sp.speaker: DRAW.
sp.p: By and by: you're welcome, good master BVFFONE.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Where's GEORGE? calme GEORGE hither, quickly.

sp.speaker: DRAW.
sp.p: What wine please you haue, sir? I'le draw you that's neat, master BVFFONE.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Away NEOPHITE, do as I bid thee, bring my deare GEORGE to me: Masse, here he comes.

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: Welcome, master CARLO.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: What! is supper ready, GEORGE?

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: I, sir, almost: will you haue the cloth laid, master CARLO?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: O, what else? are none of the gallants come, yet?

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: None yet, sir.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Stay, take mee with you, GEORGE: let mee haue a good faloyne of porke laid to the fire, presently.

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: It shall, sir.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: And withall, heare you? draw me the biggest shaft you haue, out of the butt you wot of: away, you know my meaning, GEORGE, quicke.

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: Done, sir.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I neuer hungred so much for thing in my life, as I doe to know our gallants successe at court: now is that leane bald-rib MACILENTE, that salt villaine, plotting some mischicuous deuice, and lyes a soking in their frothy humours like a drie crust, till he has drunke 'hem all vp: could the pummise but hold vp his eyes at other mens happines, in any reasonable proportion: S'lid, the slaue were to be lou'd next heauen, aboue honour, wealth, rich fare, apparell, wenches, all the delights of the belly, and the groine, whateuer.

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: Here, master CARLO.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Is't right, Boy?

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: I, sir, I assure you 'tis right.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.stage: He puts forth the drawers, and shuts the dore.
sp.p: Well said, my deare GEORGE, depart: Come, my small gymblet, you in the false scabberd, away, so. Now to you, sir Burgomaster, let's taste of your bountie.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: What, will he deale vpon such quantities of wine, alone?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: You will perceiue that, sir.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.stage: Hee sets the two cups asunder, and first drinkes with the one, and pledges with the other.
sp.p: I mary, sir, here's puritie: O, GEORGE, I could bite off his nose for this, now: Sweet rogue, he has drawne Nectar, the very soule of the grape! I'le wash my temples with some on't presently, and drinke some halfe a score draughts; 'twill heat the braine, kindle my imagination, I shall talke nothing but crackers, and fire-worke, to night. So, sir! please you to be here, sir, and I here: So.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: This is worth the obseruation, signior.

sp.speaker: CARL. 1. Cap.
sp.p: Now, sir; here's to you; and I present you with so much of my loue.

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.p: I take it kindly from you, sir, and will returne you the like proportion: but withall, sir, remembring the merry night wee had at the countesses, you know where, sir.
By heauen, you put me in minde now of a very necessarie office, which I will propose in your pledge, sir: the health of that honorable countesse, and the sweet lady that sate by her, sir.
I doe vaile to it with reuerence. And now, signior, with these ladies, I'le be bold to mixe the health of your diuine Mistris.
Doe you know her, sir?
O lord, sir, I: and in the respectfull memorie and mention of her, I could wish this wine were the most precious drugge in the world.
Good faith, sir, you doe honour me in't exceedingly.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: Whom should he personate in this, signior?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Faith, I know not, sir, obserue, obserue him.

If it were the basest filth, or mud that runnes in the channell, I am bound to pledge it, respectiuely, sir. And now, sir, here is a replenisht bowle, which I will reciprocally turne vpon you, to the health of the count FRVGALE.
The count FRVGALES health, sir? I'le pledge it on my knees, by this light.
Will you, sir? I'le drinke it on my knee, then, by the light.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: Why, this is strange!

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Ha' you heard a better drunken dialogue?
Nay, doe me right, sir.
So I doe, in good faith.
Good faith you doe not; mine was fuller.
Why, beleeue me, it was not.
Beleeue me, it was: and you doe lie.
Lie, sir?
I, sir.
S'wounds!
O, come, stab if you haue a mind to it.
Stab? dost thou thinke I dare not?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nay, I beseech you, gentlemen, what meanes this? nay, looke, for shame respect your reputations.
WHy, how now CARLO! what humour's this?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: O, my good Mischiefe! art thou come? where are the rest? where are the rest?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Faith, three of our ordinance are burst.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Burst? how comes that?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Faith, ouer-charg'd, ouer-charg'd.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: But did not the traine hold?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: O, yes, and the poore lady is irrecouerably blowne vp.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Why, but which of the munition is miscarried? ha?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Inprimis, sir PVNTARVOLO: next, the COVNTENANCE, and RESOLVTION.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: How? how for the loue of wit?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Troth, the Resolution is prou'd recreant; the Countenance hath chang'd his copie: and the passionate knight is shedding funerall teares ouer his departed dogge.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: What's his dogge dead?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Poison'd, 'tis thought: mary, how, or by whom, that's left for some cunning woman here o' the Banke-side to resolue. For my part, I know nothing, more then that wee are like to haue an exeeding melancholy supper of it.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: S'life, and I had purpos'd to be extraordinarily merry, I had drunke off a good preparatiue of old sacke here: but will they come, will they come?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p:
They will assuredly come: may, CARLO (as thou lou'st me) run ouer 'hem all freely to night, and especially the knight; spare no sulphurous
iest that may come out of that sweatie forge of thine: but ply 'hem with all manner of shot, minion, saker, culvertine, or any thing what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I warrant thee, my deare case of petrionels, so I stand not in dread of thee, but that thou'lt second me.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Why, my good Germane tapster, I will.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: What, GEORGE. Lomtero, Lomtero, &c. He dances.

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: Did you call, master CARLO?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: More nectar, GEORGE: Lomtero, &c.

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: Your meat's ready, sir, and your company were come.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Is the loyne of porke enough?

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: I, sir, it is enough.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Porke? heart, what dost thou with such a greasie dish? I thinke thou dost varnish thy face with the fat on't, it lookes so like a glew-pot.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: True, my raw-bon'd-rogue, and if thou would'st farce thy leane ribs with it too, they would not (like ragged lathes) rub out so many doublets as they doe: but thou know'st not a good dish, thou. O, it's the only nourishing meat in the world. No maruaile though that saucie, stubborne generation, the Iewes, were forbidden it: for what would they ha' done, well pamper'd with fat porke, that durst murmure at their maker out of garlicke, and onions. S'light, fed with it, the whorson strummell, patcht, goggle-ey'd Grumbledories, would ha' Gigantomachiz'd. Well said, my sweet GEORGE, fill, fill.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: This sauours too much of prophanation.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: O, seruetur ad imum, qualis ab incepto processerit, & sibi conflet. The necessite of his vaine compels a toleration: for, barre this, and dash him out of humour, before his time.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: 'Tis an Axiome in naturall philosophie, What comes neerest the nature of that it feeds, conuerts quicker to nourisment, and doth sooner essentiate. Now nothing in flesh, and entrailes, assimulates or resembles man more, then a hog, or swine—

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: True; and hee (to requite their courtesie) oftentimes d'offeth his owne nature, and puts on theirs; as when hee becomes as churlish as a hog, or as drunke as a sow: but to your conclusion.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Mary, I say, nothing resembling man more then a swine, it followes, nothing can be more nourishing: for indeed (but that it abhorres from our nice nature) if we fed one vpon another, we should shoot vp a great deale faster, and thriue much better: I referre me to your vsurous Cannibals, or such like: but since it is so contrary, porke, porke, is your only feed.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: I take it, your deuill be of the same diet; he would ne're ha' desir'd to beene incorporated into swine else. O, here comes the melancholy messe: vpon 'hem CARLO, charge, charge.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: 'Fore god, sir PVNTARVOLO, I am sorry for your heauinesse: body a me, a shrewd mischance! why, had you no vnicornes horne, nor bezoars stone about you? ha?

div.head: Act V. Scene VI.
div.stage: PVNTARVOLO, CARLO, MACILENTE, FAST. BRISKE, SOGLIARDO, FVNGOSO.

sp.p: SIr, I would request you, be silent.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Nay, to him againe.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Take comfort, good knight, if your cat ha' recouered her catarrhe, feare nothing; your dogges mischance may be holpen.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Say how (sweet CARLO) for so god mend mee, the poore knights moues draw mee into fellowship of his misfortunes. But be not discourag'd, good sir PVNTARVOLO, I am content your aduenture shall be perform'd vpon your cat.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: I beleeue you, muske cod, I beleeue you, for rather then thou would'st make present repayment, thou would'st take it vpon his owne bare returne from Calice.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nay, 'ds life, hee'ld bee content (so hee were well rid out of his company) to pay him fiue for one, at his next meeting him in Paules. But for your dogge, sir PVNTAR, if hee bee not out-right dead, there is a friend of mine, a quack-saluer, shall put life in him againe, that's certaine.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: O, no, that comes too late.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Gods precious, knight, will you suffer this?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Drawer, get me a candle, and hard waxe, presently.

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: I, and bring vp supper; for I am so melancholy.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: O, signior, where's your Resolution?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: Resolution! hang him rascall: O, CARLO, if you loue me, doe not mention him.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Why, how so? how so?

sp.speaker: SOGL.
sp.p: O, the arrant'st crocodile that euer Christian was acquainted with. By my gentrie, I shall thinke the worse of tabacco while I liue, for his sake: I did thinke him to be as tall a man—

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Nay, BVFFONE, the knight, the knight.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: S'hid, hee lookes like an image carued out of boxe, full of knots: his face is (for all the world) like a dutch purse, with the mouth downeward; his beard the tassels: and hee walkes (let mee see) as melancholy as one o' the Masters side in the Counter. Doe you heare, sir PVNTAR?

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Sir, I doe entreat you no more, but enioyne you to silence, as you affect your peace.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nay, but deare knight, vnderstand (here are none but friends, and such as wish you well) I would ha' you doe this now; Flea me your dogge presently (but in any case keepe the head) and stuffe his skin well with straw, as you see these dead monsters at Bartholmew faire.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: I shall be suddaine, I tell you.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Or if you like not that, sir, get me somewhat a lesse dog, and clap into the skin; here's a slaue about the towne here, a Iew, one YOHAN; or a fellow that makes perrukes, will glew it on artificially, it shall ne're be discern'd, besides, 'twill be so much the warmer for the hound to trauaile in, you know.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Sir PVNTARVOLO, 'death, can you be so patient?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Or thus, sir: you may haue (as you come through Germany) a familiar for little or nothing, shall turne it selfe into the shape of your dogge, or any thing (what you will) for certaine houres; 'ods my life, knight, what doe you meane? youle offer no violence, will you? hold, hold.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, you slaue, you bandog, you.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: As you loue wit, stay the enraged knight, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: By my knighthood, he that stirres in his rescue, dies. Drawer, be gone.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Murder, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: I, are you howling, you wolfe? Gentlemen, as you tender your liues, suffer no man to enter, till my reuenge be perfect. Sirha, BVFFONE, lie downe; make no exclamations, but downe: downe, you curre, or I will make thy bloud flow on my rapier hilts.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Sweet knight, hold in thy furie, and 'fore heauen, I'le honour thee more, then the Turke do's MAHOMET.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Downe (I say.) Who's there?

sp.speaker: CONS.
sp.p: Here's the Constable, open the dores.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Good, MACILENTE.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Open no dore, if the ADALANTADO of Spaine were here, he should not enter: On, helpe me with the light, gentlemen: you knocke in vaine, sir officer.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Et in Brute!

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: Sirha, close your lips, or I will drop it in thine eyes by heauen.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: O, O.

sp.speaker: CONS.
sp.p: Open the dore, or I will breake it open.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Nay, good Constable, haue patience a little, you shall come in presently, we haue almost done.

sp.speaker: PVNT.
sp.p: So; now, are you out of your humour, sir? Shift, gentlemen.
LAy hold vpon this gallant, and pursue the rest.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Lay hold on me, sir! for what?

sp.speaker: CONS.
sp.p: Mary, for your not here, sir, with the rest of your companions.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: My riot! master Constable, take heed what you doe. CARLO, did I offer any violence?

sp.speaker: CONS.
sp.p: O, sir, you see he is not in case to answere you, and that makes you so paramptorie.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Peremptorie, s'life I appeale to the drawers, if I did him any hard measure.

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: They are all gone, there's none of them will bee laid any hold on.

sp.speaker: CONS.
sp.p: Well, sir, you are like to answere till the rest can be found out.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Slid, I appeare to GEORGE, here.

sp.speaker: CONS.
sp.p: Tut, GEORGE was not here: away with him to the Counter, sirs. Come, sir, you were best get your selfe drest somewhere.

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: Good lord, that master CARLO could not take heed, and knowing what a gentleman the knight is, if hee bee angrie.

sp.speaker: DRAW.
sp.p: A poxe on 'hem, they haue left all the meate on our hands, would they were choakt with it forme.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: What, are they gone, sirs?

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: O, here's master MACILENTE.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Sirha, GEORGE, doe you see that concealement there? that napkin vnder the table?

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: Gods so, signior FVNGOSO!

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Her's good pawne for the reckoning, bee sure you keepe him here, and Ice him not goe away till I come againe, though hee offer to discharge all: Ile returne presently.

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: Sirrah, we haue a pawne for the reckoning.

sp.speaker: DRAW.
sp.p: What? of MACILENTE?

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: No, looke vnder the table.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I hope, all be quiet now: if I can get but forth of this street, I care not, masters, I pray you tell me, is the Constable gone?

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: What? master FVNGOSO?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Was't not a good deuice this same of me, sirs?

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: Yes saith; ha' you beene here all this while?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: O god, I▪ good sir, looke, and the coast be cleere, I'ld faine be going.

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: Al's cleere, sir, but the reckoning; and that you must cleare, and pay before you goe, I assure you.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I pay? Slight, I eate not a bit since I came into the house, yet.

sp.speaker: DRAW.
sp.p: Why, you may when you please, sir, 'tis all readie below, that was bespoken.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Bespoken? not by me, I hope?

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: By you, sir? I know not that: but 'twas for you, and your companie, I am sure.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: My companie? S'lid, I was an inuited guest, so I was.

sp.speaker: DRAW.
sp.p: Faith, we haue no thing to doe with that, sir, they're all gone but you, and we must be answer'd; that's the short and the long on't.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Nay, if you will grow to extremities, my masters, then would this pot, cup, and all were in my belly, if I haue a crosse about me.

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: What, and haue such apparell? doe not say so, signior, that mightily discredits your clothes.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: As I am an honest man, my taylor had all my monie this morning, and yet I must be faine to alter my sute too: good sirs, let me goe, 'tis friday night, and in good truth I haue no stomacke in the world, to eate anie thing.

sp.speaker: DRAW.
sp.p: That's no matter, so you pay, sir.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Pay? gods light, with what conscience can you aske me to pay that I neuer dranke for?

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: Yes, sir, I did see you drinke once.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: By this cup, (which is siluer) but you did not, you doe mee infinite wrong, I look't in the pot once, indeed, but I did not drinke.

sp.speaker: DRAW.
sp.p: Well sir, if you can satisfie our master, it shall bee all one to vs. (by and by.)

sp.speaker: CORD.
sp.p: Lose not your selfe now signior.

TVt, sir, you did beare too hard a conceit of me in that, but I will now make my loue to you most transparent, in spight of any dust of suspition, that may bee raysed to cloud it: and henceforth, since I see it is so against your humour, I will neuer labour to perswade you.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Why, I thanke you, signior, but what's that you tell mee may concerne my peace so much?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p:
Faith, sir, 'tis thus. Your wiues brother, signior FVNGOSO, being at supper to night at a tauerne, with a sort of gallants, there happened some diuision amongst 'hem, and he is left in pawne for the reckoning: now, if euer you looke that time shall present you with a happie occasion to doe your wife some gracious and acceptable seruice, take hold of this opportunitie, and presently goe, and redeeme him; for, being her
brother, and his credit so amply engag'd as now it is, when she shall heare (as hee cannot himselfe, but hee must out of extremitie report it) that you came, and offered your selfe so kindly, and with that respect of his reputation, why, the benefit cannot but make her dote, and grow madde of your affections.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Now, by heauen, MACILENTE, I acknowledge my selfe exceedingly indebted to you, by this kinde tender of your loue; and I am sorrie to remember that I was euer so rude, to neglect a friend of your importance: bring mee shooes, and a cloke there, I was going to bed, if you had not come, what tauerne is it?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: The Mitre, sir.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: O, why FIDO, my shooes. Good faith it cannot but please her exceedingly.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Come, I marle what peece of nightwork you haue in hand now, that you call for your cloke, and your shooes! what, is this your Pandar?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: O, sweet wife, speake lower, I would not he should heare thee for a world—

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Hang him rascall, I cannot abide him for his trecherie, with his wilde quick-set beard there. Whither goe you now with him?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: No whither with him, deare wife, I goe alone to a place, from whence I will returne instantly. Good MACILENTE, acquaint not her with it by any meanes, it may come so much the more accepted, frame some other answere. I'le come backe immediately.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Nay, and I be not worthie to know whither you goe, stay, till I take knowledge of your comming backe.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Heare you, mistresse DELIRO.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: So sir, and what say you?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Faith ladie, my intents will not deserue this slight respect, when you shall know 'hem.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Your intents? why, what may your intents bee, for god sake!

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Troth, the time allowes no circumstance, ladie, therefore know, this was but a deuice to remoue your husband hence, and bestow him securely, whilest (with more conueniencie) I might report to you a misfortune that hath happened to Monsieur BRISKE— nay comfort, sweet ladie. This night (being at supper a sort of young gallants committed a riot, for the which he (onely) is apprehended and carried to the Counter, where if your husband, and other creditours should but haue knowledge of him, the poore gentleman were vndone for euer.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Aye me! that he were.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Now therefore, if you can thinke vpon any present meanes for his deliuerie, doe not forslow it. A bribe to the officer that committed him, will doe it.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: O god, sir, he shall not want for a bribe: pray you, will you commend me to him, and say I'le visit him presently?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p:
No, ladie, I shall doe you better seruice, in protracting your
husbands returne, that you may goe with more safetie.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Good truth, so you may: farewell, good sir. Lord, how a woman may be mistaken in a man? I would haue sworne vpon all the testaments in the world, he had not lou'd master BRISKE. Bring me my keyes there, maide. Alasse, good gentleman, if all I haue i' this earthly world will pleasure him, it shall be at his seruice.

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: How MACILENTE sweates i'this busines, if you marke him.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: I, you shall see the true picture of spight anon: here comes the pawne, and his redeemer.
COme, brother, be not discourag'd for this, man, what?

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: No truly, I am not discourag'd, but I protest to you, brother, I haue done imitating any more gallants either in purse or apparell, but as shall become a gentleman, for good carriage, or so.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: You say well. This is all, i' the bill here? is't not?

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: I, sir.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: There's your monie, tell it: and brother, I am glad I met with so good occasion to shew my loue to you.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I will studie to deserue it in good truth, and I liue.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: What, is't right?

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: I, sir, and I thanke you.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Let me haue a capons legge sau'd, now the reckoning is paid.

sp.speaker: GEOR.
sp.p: You shall, sir.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Where's signior DELIRO?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: Here, MACILENTE.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Harke you, sir, ha' you dispatcht this same?

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: I marie haue I.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Well then, I can tell you newes, BRISKE is i'the Counter.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: I'the Counter?

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: 'Tis true, sir, committed for the stirre here to night. Now would I haue you send your brother home afore, with the report of this your kindnesse done him, to his sister, which will so pleasingly possesse her, and out of his mouth too, that i' the meane time you may clap your action on BRISKE, and your wife (being in so happie a moode) cannot entertaine it ill, by any meanes.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: 'Tis verie true, she cannot indeed, I thinke.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Thinke? why 'tis past thought, you shall neuer meet the like opportunitie, I assure you.

sp.speaker: DELI.
sp.p: I will doe it. Brother, pray you goe home afore, this gentleman, and I haue some priuate businesse; and tell my sweet wife, I'le come presently.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: I will, brother.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: And, signior, acquaint your sister, how liberally and out of his bountie, your brother has vs'd you. (Doe you see?) made you a man of good reckoning; redeem'd that you neuer were possest of, credit; gaue you as gentleman-like termes as might be; found no fault with your comming behind the fashion; nor nothing.

sp.speaker: FVNG.
sp.p: Nay, I am out of those humours now.

sp.speaker: MACI.
sp.p: Well, if you be out, keepe your distance, and be not made a shot-clog any more. Come, signior, let's make haste.
O Master FASTIDIVS, what pitty is't to see so sweet a man as you are, in so sowre a place?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: As vpon her lips, do's shee meane?

sp.speaker: MIT.
sp.p: O, this is to be imagin'd the Counter, belike?

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: Troth, faire lady, 'tis first the pleasure of the Fates, and next of the Constable, to haue it so: but, I am patient, and indeed comforted the more in your kind visitation.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: Nay, you shall bee comforted in mee, more then this, if you please, sir. I sent you word by my brother, sir, that my husband laid to rest you this morning, I know not whether you receiu'd it, or no.

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: No, beleeue it, sweet creature, your brother gaue me no such intelligence.

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: O, the lord!

sp.speaker: FAST.
sp.p: But has your husband any such purpose?

sp.speaker: FALL.
sp.p: O sweet master BRISKE, yes: and therefore be presently discharg'd, for if he come with his actions vpon you (lord deliuer you) you are in for one halfe a score yeere; he kept a poore man in Ludgate once, twelue yeere, for sixteene shillings.
